title: The FSB in 2021:  Addressing Financial Stability Challenges in an Age of Interconnectedness, Innovation, and Change
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision and Chair of the Financial Stability Board Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='A little over 420 years ago, a crowd-pleasing local fabler on a lightly populated island in the North Atlantic made popular a phrase that has entered into our language: "Beware the Ides of March." Caesar ignored the soothsayer, and the results weren\'t good; if recent history is any indication, perhaps we should keep the warning in mind as well. In March 2008, we witnessed a significant domino fall in a chain of events that sparked the Global Financial Crisis (GFC) with the collapse and sale of Bear Stearns.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Indeed, this time last year, both domestically and internationally, the financial regulatory community fortified itself as COVID-19 and related containment measures spread across the globe, what I refer to as the COVID event. The Financial Stability Board (FSB) moved into high gear, holding weekly, and even daily, meetings with the most senior leaders of central banks, finance ministries, and market regulators—to share information and shape a synchronized global approach to the crisis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This NBFI work alone would be an ambitious agenda. But I believe the FSB is well equipped to address this challenge while also furthering the other important elements of our broad agenda. Let me spend some time talking about another of these important objectives: enhancing cross-border payments.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are, of course, continuing to closely monitor vulnerabilities stemming from the COVID event, including the rise in nonfinancial sector debt and measures of bond and equity market valuations. In April, the FSB will report on key considerations involved in amending or unwinding COVID-19 support measures, as appropriate.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Yet, if the benefits of TBTF reforms are to be fully realized, there remains further work to do. The FSB outlines this work in its forthcoming evaluation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Transitioning away from LIBOR is a significant undertaking that the FSB has been engaged in for almost a decade. The FSB set forth a roadmap for clear actions that financial firms and their clients can take to ensure a smooth transition away from LIBOR.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The span of territory and topics covered can admittedly seem bewildering at times—I've covered only a few of them today.", theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='It is my pleasure to meet virtually with you today at the 2021 Institute of International Finance (IIF) Washington Policy Summit. I regret that we are not doing this session in person, but I do hope next time we will be gathering together in Washington. I look forward, as always, to a conversation with my good friend and one-time colleague Tim Adams, but first, please allow me to offer a few remarks on the economic outlook, Federal Reserve monetary policy, and our new monetary policy framework.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the second quarter of last year, the COVID-19 pandemic and the mitigation efforts put in place to contain it delivered the most severe blow to the U.S. economy since the Great Depression. Gross domestic product (GDP) collapsed at a roughly 31.5 percent annual rate in the second quarter of 2020, more than 22 million jobs were lost in March and April, and the unemployment rate rose from a 50-year low of 3.5 percent in February to almost 15 percent in April.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As with overall economic activity, conditions in the labor market have recently improved. Employment rose by 379,000 in February, as the leisure and hospitality sector recouped about two-thirds of the jobs that were lost in December and January.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="It is worth highlighting that in the baseline projections of the FOMC presented in the latest SEP released last week, my colleagues and I substantially revised up our outlook for the economy, projecting a relatively rapid return to levels of employment and inflation consistent with the Federal Reserve's statutory mandate as compared with the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With regards to inflation, the median inflation projection of FOMC participants is 2.4 percent this year and declines to 2 percent next year before moving back up to 2.1 percent in 2023.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recent FOMC Decisions and the New Monetary Policy Framework At our most recent FOMC meetings, the Committee made important changes to our policy statement that upgraded our forward guidance about the future path of the federal funds rate and asset purchases, and that also provided unprecedented information about our policy reaction function.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, in our December FOMC statement, the Committee combined our forward guidance for the federal funds rate with enhanced, outcome-based guidance about our asset purchases. title: The Economic Outlook and Prospects for Small Business
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The views expressed here are my own and are not necessarily those of my Federal Open Market Committee colleagues. I would also like to acknowledge the valuable contributions of Federal Reserve staff member Wendy Dunn. Return to text', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As we all know, starting in late February or March of last year, widespread economic and social lockdowns and other effects of the COVID-19 pandemic caused the swiftest and deepest contraction in employment and economic activity since the Great Depression. Money markets, the Treasury market, and other parts of the financial system seized up, and there were fears of another severe financial crisis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although economic activity in the travel, leisure, and hospitality sectors has continued to lag the recovery, there have been some bright spots elsewhere. title: Keynote Remarks
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Since 2017, when Andrew Bailey first announced that the U.K. Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) had secured a voluntary agreement with the remaining panel banks submitting to LIBOR to continue their submissions through 2021, we in the official sector have emphasized that LIBOR would eventually end, but the market has lacked clarity on exactly when it would end.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although one might have expected that a statement from the regulator that a benchmark would stop might cause people to think twice before using it even if the exact end date were uncertain, many have kept using LIBOR.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Adjusting to a new reality can be difficult, so let me be clear: These statements are definitive.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Seeking to provide the same kind of clear statement about supervisory expectations, U.S. regulators issued supervisory guidance in November of last year.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="It is helpful to think about these separate announcements as essential pieces of a map, which, once put together, provide a complete picture of the path from here to LIBOR's end.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Three years ago, the ARRC estimated that there were approximately $200 trillion in outstanding financial contracts using USD LIBOR as a reference rate.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Many of those contracts have better fallback language than was once the case; the ARRC has spent considerable time in recommending more robust fallback language for new LIBOR cash products, and ISDA has now published its IBOR protocol, which has allowed market participants to incorporate more robust fallbacks into legacy derivatives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The path we have laid out—ending new use of LIBOR while providing further time for existing contracts to mature—will give businesses, consumers, and all parties to a contract more certainty that they can count on the original terms of a legacy contract until mid-2023.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, we will also be left with the 33 percent of contracts that will not mature before mid-2023, an estimated $74 trillion in financial contracts.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The continued publication of LIBOR will help provide more time to make sure that we are fully ready with the necessary solutions when LIBOR stops.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Having talked about the end game for legacy contracts, let me return to the other key component of the plan, winding down new use of dollar LIBOR.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Examiners are looking closely to see whether firms have comprehensively assessed their exposure to LIBOR and, if exposures are sizable and complex, have strong plans in place.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Before I turn this over to Tom Wipf and Tushar Morzaria, let me thank them for all of the work that they have done with the ARRC and the Working Group on Sterling Risk-Free Rates.', theme='other')]

title: Closing Remarks
speaker: Chair Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Last year, the Group of Twenty (G-20) asked the Financial Stability Board (FSB) to coordinate the development of a roadmap on how the global community could enhance cross-border payments. It has long been acknowledged that the existing system, while safe and dependable, suffers from frictions, including processes that make it difficult to comply with anti-money-laundering and countering-terrorist-financing requirements, difficulty in managing payments across time zones, and, in certain areas, a reliance on outdated technology. Moreover, these frictions contribute to higher costs for cross-border transactions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As with many aspects of life these days, the COVID-19 pandemic has shined a light on the less efficient areas of our current payment system and accelerated the desire for improvement and digitalization. Even before the pandemic, advancements in the private sector served as a catalyst to get the attention of consumers and to prompt more engagement by the public sector.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The goal of the FSB roadmap is simple—to create an ecosystem for cross-border payments that is faster, cheaper, more transparent, and more inclusive. A year into the process, I am encouraged that we are making meaningful progress. The stage 3 report released in October laid out a practical set of steps for moving ahead on the 19 building blocks that will bring about an improved system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Indeed, the themes discussed in the four sessions of the conference today correspond well to approaches described in the building blocks. The title of the first panel sets up a choice between 'improving existing rails or laying new tracks.' As the roadmap makes clear, one of the keys to moving forward will be doing both—improving the existing system where we can while also evaluating the potential of and the best uses for emerging technologies.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve is working to improve the current system through the introduction of instant or fast payments via the FedNow Service. The service will be designed to maintain uninterrupted processing—24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year—with security features that will ensure payment integrity and data security. The target launch date is sometime in 2023.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve is also doing its part to examine the role of new technologies. Experiments with central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) are being conducted at the Board of Governors, as well as complementary efforts by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston in collaboration with researchers at MIT.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Improvements in the global payments system will come not just from the public sector, but from the private sector as well. As today's second panel, 'Of Lions and Unicorns,' described, the private sector has the experience and expertise to develop consumer-facing infrastructure that improves and simplifies how the public engages with the financial system.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="And the last two panels of the day, 'Addressing Legal Barriers to Cross-Border Payments' and 'Harmonised Data to Oil the Cross-Border Payments Machinery,' highlight that improving the system must be a collaborative effort. By definition, cross-border payments involve multiple jurisdictions.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And, finally, it is only by engaging all stakeholders—policymakers, private-sector participants, and academia—as this conference is doing, that we will achieve the improved payments ecosystem we are striving toward.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The COVID crisis has brought into even sharper focus the need to address the limitations of our current arrangements for cross-border payments. And as this conference amply demonstrates, despite the challenges of this last year, we still have been able to make important progress.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. See Financial Stability Board (2020), Enhancing Cross-Border Payments: Stage 3 Roadmap (PDF) (Basel, Switzerland: FSB, October). Return to text', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="2. See Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (2020), 'Federal Reserve Announces Details of New 24x7x365 Interbank Settlement Service with Clearing Functionality to Support Instant Payments in the United States,' press release, August 6.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="3. See Bank for International Settlements (2020), 'Central Banks and BIS Publish First Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) Report Laying Out Key Requirements,' press release, October 9.", theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy: An Update

dark winter with elevated case counts and setbacks on service-sector jobs, case counts have come down and spending is picking up.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the progress on vaccinations is promising, jobs are currently down by 10 million relative to pre-pandemic levels.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Labor force participation by prime-age workers stands lower now, on net, than it did in June after it had bounced back partway from the decline in April.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Roughly 90 percent of the shortfall in private payroll employment relative to the pre-COVID level is concentrated in service-providing industries.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Realized inflation remains low, although inflation expectations appear to have moved closer to our 2 percent longer-run target.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In many foreign countries, growth moderated at the end of 2020, as a spike in COVID hospitalizations and deaths led to tighter public health restrictions in many economies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Outlook So, what do these developments suggest for the U.S. outlook?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation is likely to temporarily rise above 2 percent on a 12-month basis when the low March and April price readings from last year fall out of our preferred 12-month PCE measure.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When considering the inflation outlook, it is important to remember that inflation has averaged slightly below 2 percent for over a quarter-century.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Monetary Policy With that outlook in mind, let me turn to monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These changes mean that we will not tighten monetary policy solely in response to a strong labor market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Today the economy remains far from our goals in terms of both employment and title: Some Preliminary Financial Stability Lessons from the COVID-19 Shock

title: Themistocles and the Mathematicians: The Role of Stress Testing
speaker: Vice Chair for Supervision Randal K. Quarles
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='One of the principal themes of human history—and certainly of economic history—is that of a sudden technological breakthrough originally deployed for one purpose being gradually refined over time until new and better versions of it are eventually deployed for a much broader range of purposes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The breakthrough supplies the drama, but it's the steady incremental improvement over time that makes the greatest difference. The Phoenicians dramatically improved the speed and cargo load of their commercial voyages with the invention of the trireme—massive boats, powered with three tiers of oarsmen, rather than the standard one or two—dispatched from Tyre and Sidon in the service of exploration, commerce, and colonization.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the world of bank supervision, our equivalent of the trireme has been the stress test. The initial innovation of stress testing gave us an urgently needed tool to measure how much additional capital banks with mounting losses needed to survive the financial crisis more than a decade ago.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Today, I'd like to share with you my perspective about how stress testing has enhanced the credibility of our capital adequacy framework, highlight some features of the upcoming stress test, and offer some thoughts on the importance of continued innovation in supervision.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The 2020 Stress Tests We now use stress testing in two important but different ways: to set capital requirements during normal times and to assess capital adequacy during exigent times.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While this new framework has the same goal as the previous Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) framework—using forward-looking analysis to help ensure that banks have sufficient capital to survive a severe recession while still being able to lend to businesses and household—it integrates our stress testing regime with our ongoing capital requirements so that large banks now have a single suite of dynamic and risk-sensitive capital requirements.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is useful here to pause and put stress testing in the context of bank supervision in general. Both supervision and stress testing specifically have roles during normal times as well as times of stress, but those roles are somewhat different depending on the circumstances.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That includes conditions that few could have imagined, such as those that descended last spring. The temporary shutdown of large segments of the economy caused an unprecedentedly large and swift drop in economic activity.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We responded to that abrupt change in environment by adapting our stress testing tools to help assess bank capital adequacy under these extraordinary circumstances.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Fed's stress testing models are subject to continual development by experts in credit risk measurement, borrower behavior, and financial markets.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our disclosures of the results stemming from those models, along with transparency about the model assumptions, have given banks, markets, and the broader public a lens through which to understand risk in the system.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Looking Ahead to the 2021 Stress Test Continuing in that tradition, two weeks ago we initiated the 2021 stress test with the publication of this cycle's stress scenarios.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In March, we will publish the details of the methodologies that underlie our models. This will mark the third year since we enhanced the disclosures to provide significantly more information about the stress testing models relative to earlier years.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Future Innovation in Stress Testing As we look to the future, the Fed must continue to innovate so that stress testing remains effective.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Over the longer term, we must continue to sharpen our thinking around the interrelationships between bank risk and broader changes, such as advancing technologies and growth in non-bank finance.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At the same time, we regularly get calls from the public to review various aspects of our models. For example, in recent years, representatives from an affordable housing group noted that the global market shock for real estate investments also affected certain lower-risk public welfare investments, thereby discouraging investment in affordable housing.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='More recently, we received feedback from banks via appeals of their stress capital buffers. I was encouraged by the fact that a number of the issues the banks raised were already on our research agenda.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Drawing on that experience, I believe there is a need for more data and data-driven analysis broadly in supervision, which is related to the larger goal of enhanced transparency.', theme='other')]

title: How Should We Think about Full Employment in the Federal Reserve's Dual Mandate?
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This text discusses the concept of full employment in the context of monetary policy and its significance for the US economy. It highlights the importance of promoting maximum employment as a coequal objective alongside price stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The discussion begins with an overview of the evolution of central banking goals, from a focus on economic growth to the dual mandate of maximum employment and price stability. The Humphrey-Hawkins Act of 1978 introduced the full-employment objective, but it was never explicitly made a statutory goal by Congress.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The text notes that the Federal Reserve's statutory responsibilities have evolved over time, with the central bank now emphasizing its role in promoting both maximum employment and price stability. This dual mandate is shared with other major economies, such as Australia and New Zealand, which also prioritize full employment alongside price stability.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The discussion highlights the significance of achieving a broad-based and inclusive recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly for marginalized groups such as people of color and frontline workers. It emphasizes the importance of considering disparities in job loss during the pandemic and promoting policies to address these issues.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Key metrics used to track labor market conditions include the unemployment rate, employment-population ratio (EPOP), participation rate, and prime-age employment rate. The text highlights that the EPOP is a particularly useful measure for assessing maximum employment, as it accounts for both employed and unemployed individuals who are actively seeking work.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The discussion also touches on the concept of involuntary part-time work and its significance in tracking labor market conditions. It notes that the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) has provided estimates of the likely size of this effect on the unemployment rate during the pandemic.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, the text highlights research findings on racial gaps in labor market outcomes over the last four decades and discusses the importance of achieving a broad-based and inclusive recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. It emphasizes that policymakers should consider disparities in job loss during the pandemic and promote policies to address these issues.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some key points from the text include:', theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='A number of macroeconomic data releases have been weaker than expected in recent months. Spending on services has continued to remain well below pre-pandemic levels, particularly in contact-intensive sectors, including travel, leisure, and hospitality.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although more than half of the 22 million jobs that were lost last spring have been regained, the unemployment rate remained elevated at 6.3 percent in January, and once one factors in the decline in the labor force since the onset of the pandemic and misclassification, the true unemployment rate is closer to 10 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Core PCE (personal consumption expenditures) inflation is running at just 1.5 percent, and, for those sectors that have been most adversely affected by the pandemic, price increases remain subdued.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The median FOMC participant projected in December that by the end of 2023—a little less than three years from now—the unemployment rate will have fallen below 4 percent, and PCE inflation will have returned to 2 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recent macroeconomic data releases have been weaker than expected in recent months. Spending on services has continued to remain well below pre-pandemic levels, particularly in contact-intensive sectors, including travel, leisure, and hospitality.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Retail sales stepped up considerably in January, retracing the decline late last year.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The housing sector has more than fully recovered from the downturn, supported in part by low mortgage interest rates.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Business investment and manufacturing production have also rebounded robustly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is worth highlighting that in the baseline projections of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) presented in the latest Summary of Economic Projections, released last December, most of my colleagues and I revised up our outlooks for the economy over the medium term.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Following the GFC, it took more than eight years for employment and inflation to return to similar mandate-consistent levels.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the winter surge in new COVID cases and the spread of new variants of the virus are cause for concern as well as a source of downside risk to the very near-term outlook, the welcome news on the development of several effective vaccines and the passage by the Congress in late December of a package of fiscal relief measures indicate to me that the prospects for the economy in 2021 and beyond have brightened and the downside risk to the outlook has diminished.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recent FOMC Decisions and the New Monetary Policy Framework', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At our most recent FOMC meetings, the Committee made important changes to our policy statement that upgraded our forward guidance about the future path of the federal funds rate and asset purchases.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these outcomes—as well as our maximum-employment mandate—are achieved.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, in the December statement, we combined our forward guidance for the federal funds rate with enhanced, outcome-based guidance about our asset purchases.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The changes to the policy statement that we made over the past few FOMC meetings bring our policy guidance in line with the new framework outlined in the revised Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy that the Committee approved last August.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This language means that going forward, a low unemployment rate, in and of itself, will not be sufficient to trigger a tightening of monetary policy absent any evidence from other indicators that inflation is at risk of moving above mandate-consistent levels.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While this new framework represents a robust evolution in our monetary policy strategy, this strategy is in service to the dual-mandate goals of monetary policy assigned to the Federal Reserve by the Congress—maximum employment and price stability—which remain unchanged.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Concluding Remarks', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While our interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so as the recovery progresses, it will take some time for economic activity and employment to return to levels that prevailed at the business cycle peak reached last February.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help ensure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust and rapid as possible.', theme='other')]

title: Economic Inclusion in Lower-Income Communities
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='At the Federal Reserve, our community development mission is to promote economic growth and financial stability across the country, particularly in vulnerable communities. The ability to access quality education and training to build workforce skills is critical for low-income workers seeking greater opportunity for themselves and their families.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These issues have taken on even greater importance over the past year. The COVID-19 pandemic has upended our personal and professional lives and continues to cause economic hardship for many Americans.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Information from the Federal Reserve Board's Survey of Household Economics and Decisionmaking, or SHED, provides evidence of these disparities.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The survey showed that employment disruptions and financial challenges disproportionately affected people of color and low-income families.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For many families, the pandemic exacerbated existing financial challenges.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Economic mobility is largely driven by family financial stability and geographic resources such as transportation, quality education, and broadband access.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Fed's research and its ongoing work in community development show that there is no quick fix for the disparities in household financial stability.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This brings me to the importance of collaboration to address multidimensional community issues.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Today, we are here to celebrate Advance Together, one such effort to foster economic inclusion through innovative and collaborative programs.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The four winners that we are honoring today are the Educate Midland and Education Partnership of the Permian Basin; the Big Country Manufacturing Alliance, based in Abilene;', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It has truly been a pleasure to learn about the unique and innovative efforts each of you are undertaking to address the education and workforce challenges in your own communities.', theme='employment')]

title: My Perspective on Bank Regulation and Supervision
speaker: Governor Michelle W. Bowman
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It's fair to say that a lot has happened over the past two years. It is an understatement to say that the COVID-19 pandemic has created significant challenges inside and outside the banking sector.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Since becoming a member of the Federal Reserve Board, I have made it a priority to enhance the Federal Reserve's dialogue with community bankers. I have embarked on an effort to meet with the leaders of every community bank and regional bank supervised by the Federal Reserve.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Today, I would like to share my approach to supervision and regulation, which has helped guide the Fed's efforts to improve oversight of community banks over the past few years and shaped our priorities for 2021 and beyond.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The first principle is fundamental to regulation but sometimes bears repeating—regulation should always strike the right balance. For banking regulation, that means a balance between actions that promote safety and soundness and actions that promote an acceptable and manageable level of risk-taking.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The second principle is that the regulatory framework should be effective, but also efficient, and that means assessing the impact of the requirements. For the Federal Reserve, it means that we consider both a rule's benefit to safety and soundness and any potential negative effect...", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The third principle is that regulation and supervision should be consistent, transparent, and fair. Regulators are obligated by law to act in this manner, and it also makes good practical sense.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A final principle that flows from consistency, transparency, and fairness is that rules and supervisory judgments must have a legitimate prudential purpose, and in the majority of cases must not be solely punitive.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These principles that guide my approach to regulation and supervision are consistent with many of the major steps that the Federal Reserve has taken to improve community bank oversight since the implementation of the rules following the 2008 financial crisis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Many of the most important improvements to the Federal Reserve's regulatory framework involve tailoring rules to fit to the size, business model, and risk profiles of community banks.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These improvements in regulation and supervision have helped right the balance I spoke of earlier between safety and soundness and consumer protection, on the one hand, and the ability to provide financial services...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a part of this approach, I have also prioritized efforts to improve the consistency, transparency, and reasonableness of regulation and supervision.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I'd like to expand on one important area of focus, which is essential to the future success of the community banking sector: accessible innovation and technology integration.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Technological developments and financial market evolution are quickly escalating competition in the banking industry, and our approach to analyzing the competitive effects of mergers and acquisitions needs to keep pace.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Soon after the pandemic began early last year, the Federal Reserve took several actions to support community banks and their ability to help affected customers.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me conclude by again commending the important role that community banks have played in providing financial services during these challenging times.', theme='other')]

title: The Federal Reserve's New Framework: Context and Consequences
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The global economy is facing a low-rate environment due to the COVID-19 pandemic and other economic factors.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='He explains that the Federal Reserve has developed a new flexible average inflation-targeting framework, which combines two monetary policy strategies:', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The framework aims to achieve an average inflation rate of 2% over time, with a moderate overshoot above 2% when inflation is persistently below this goal.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Clarida emphasizes that maximum employment is not directly measurable and changes over time due to non-monetary factors affecting the labor market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The relevant policy rule benchmark after the conditions for policy normalization have been met will be an inertial Taylor-type rule with a coefficient of zero on the unemployment gap, ...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Clarida concludes that the new framework represents an evolution in monetary policy strategy, rather than a revolution.', theme='other')]

title: U.S. Economic Outlook and Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chair Richard H. Clarida
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='It is my pleasure to meet virtually with you today at the Council on Foreign Relations.1 I regret that we are not doing this session in person, as we did last year, and I hope the next time I am back, we will be gathering together in New York City again. I look forward to my conversation with Steve Liesman and to your questions, but first, please allow me to offer a few remarks on the economic outlook, Federal Reserve monetary policy, and our new monetary policy framework.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the second quarter of last year, the COVID-19 (coronavirus disease 2019) pandemic and the mitigation efforts put in place to contain it delivered the most severe blow to the U.S. economy since the Great Depression.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Household spending on goods, especially durable goods, has been strong and has moved above its pre-pandemic level, supported in part by federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In contrast, spending on services remains well below pre-pandemic levels, particularly in sectors that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the labor market, more than half of the 22 million jobs that were lost in March and April have been regained, as many people were able to return to work.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation, following large declines in the spring of 2020, picked up over the summer but has leveled out more recently; for those sectors that have been most adversely affected by the pandemic, price increases remain subdued.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While gross domestic product growth in the fourth quarter downshifted from the once-in-a-century 33 percent annualized rate of growth reported in the third quarter...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...it is clear that since the spring of 2020, the economy has turned out to be more resilient in adapting to the virus, and more responsive to monetary and fiscal policy support, than many predicted.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Indeed, it is worth highlighting that in the baseline projections of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) summarized in the latest Summary of Economic Projections (SEP), most of my colleagues and I revised up our outlook for the economy over the medium term, projecting a relatively rapid return to levels of employment and inflation consistent with the Federal Reserve's statutory mandate as compared with the recovery from the Global Financial Crisis (GFC).", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In particular, the median FOMC participant projects that by the end of 2023—a little less than three years from now—the unemployment rate will have fallen below 4 percent, and PCE (personal consumption expenditures) inflation will have returned to 2 percent.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Following the GFC, it took more than eight years for employment and inflation to return to similar mandate-consistent levels.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the recent surge in new COVID cases and hospitalizations is cause for concern and a source of downside risk to the very near-term outlook...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...the welcome news on the development of several effective vaccines indicates to me that the prospects for the economy in 2021 and beyond have brightened and the downside risk to the outlook has diminished.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The two new SEP charts that we released for the first time following the December FOMC meeting speak to these issues by providing information on how the risks and uncertainties that surround the modal or baseline projections have evolved over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although a little more than half of participants judged risks to be broadly balanced for economic activity, a similar number continued to see risks weighted to the downside for inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At our most recent FOMC meetings, the Committee made important changes to our policy statement that upgraded our forward guidance about the future path of the federal funds rate and asset purchases...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...and that also provided unprecedented information about our policy reaction function.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As announced in the September statement and reiterated in November and December, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent...', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...our policy will aim to achieve inflation outcomes that keep inflation expectations well anchored at our 2 percent longer-run goal.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these outcomes—as well as our maximum-employment mandate—are achieved.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, in the December statement, we combined our forward guidance for the federal fund rate with enhanced, outcome-based guidance about our asset purchases...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...We indicated that we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and our holdings of agency mortgage-backed securities by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The changes to the policy statement that we made over the fall bring our policy guidance in line with the new framework outlined in the revised Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy that the Committee approved last August.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In our new framework, we acknowledge that policy decisions going forward will be based on the FOMC's estimates of 'shortfalls [emphasis added] of employment from its maximum level'—not 'deviations'.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With regard to our price-stability mandate...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...while the new statement maintains our definition that the longer-run goal for inflation is 2 percent, it elevates the importance—and the challenge—of keeping inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent in a world in which an effective-lower-bound constraint is, in downturns, binding on the federal funds rate.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To this end...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="...the new statement conveys the Committee's judgment that, in order to anchor expectations at the 2 percent level consistent with price stability, it 'seeks to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time', and—in the same sentence—that therefore 'following periods when inflation has been running persistently below 2 percent, appropriate monetary policy will likely aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time'.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As Chair Powell indicated in his Jackson Hole remarks...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="...we think of our new framework as an evolution from 'flexible inflation targeting' to 'flexible average inflation targeting'.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While this new framework represents a robust evolution in our monetary policy strategy...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...this strategy is in service to the dual-mandate goals of monetary policy assigned to the Federal Reserve by the Congress—maximum employment and price stability—which remain unchanged.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While our interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so as the recovery progresses...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...it will take some time for economic activity and employment to return to levels that prevailed at the business cycle peak reached last February.', theme='employment')]

title: Modernizing and Strengthening CRA Regulations: A Conversation with the  Consumer Bankers Association
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The CRA officers and teams at your institutions play an important role in identifying community priorities and building partnerships with stakeholders to implement effective CRA programs.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We believe that the CRA remains an important tool to promote economic and financial inclusion, and we have specifically asked for feedback about what modifications and approaches would strengthen CRA regulatory implementation in addressing ongoing systemic inequity in credit access for minority individuals and communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We're looking forward to feedback on these big-picture questions and objectives in addition to the specific proposals discussed in the ANPR. title: Strengthening the CRA to Meet the Challenges of Our Time
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) is a federal law that encourages banks and thrifts to meet the credit needs of the communities in which they operate. The CRA requires depository institutions to assess their own performance on a quarterly basis and submit an annual report to regulators detailing their efforts.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some key points from the ANPR include:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="1.  **New Metrics-Based Evaluation Framework**: The proposed rule would introduce a metrics-based evaluation framework for large retail banks, allowing regulators to compare banks' performance across various communities and providing more clarity on what activities qualify for CRA credit.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2.  **Community Development Activities Clarification**: The ANPR aims to clarify which community development activities qualify under the CRA, making it easier for banks to determine whether their investments will receive CRA credit. This includes a list of illustrative but not exhaustive activities that are eligible.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3.  **Reduced Data Collection and Reporting Burden**: The proposed rule seeks to reduce the data collection and reporting burden on smaller banks by exempting them from deposit and certain other data collection requirements, except in limited circumstances.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4.  **Flexibility for Small Banks in Rural Areas**: The ANPR provides greater clarity and flexibility for small banks operating in rural areas, allowing them to tailor their assessment area definition without expanding it to include parts of counties where they do not have a physical presence.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5.  **Public Comment Period**: The Federal Reserve Board has initiated an extended 120-day comment period to gather feedback from stakeholders, reflecting the importance of this rulemaking process and the need for a broad range of input from various groups.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='6.  **Collaboration Among Banking Agencies**: The ANPR is intended to build a foundation for the banking agencies (Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency) to converge on a consistent approach to strengthening the CRA that has broad support among stakeholders.', theme='other')]

title: The Federal Reserve’s New Monetary Policy Framework: A Robust Evolution

anchor longer-run inflation expectations at 2 percent.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="2. **Increased Emphasis on Achieving Mandated Goals:** The statement clarifies the Fed's commitment to emphasizes the Fed's resolve to use its full range of tools, including forward guidance, to achieve its goals.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Clarification on Use of Operational Inflation
