theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Primarily, I believe it is a remarkable, and perhaps underappreciated, achievement that the economy has returned to near-full employment in a relatively short time after the Great Recession, given the historical experience following a financial crisis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Turning briefly to recent developments, the pattern of high employment growth and low productivity growth that we have seen in recent years has continued this year. So far in 2016, nonfarm payroll gains have averaged about 185,000 per month--down from last year's pace of 230,000, but still more than enough to represent a continued improvement in labor market conditions.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Output growth has been much less impressive. Over the four quarters ending this spring, real GDP is now estimated to have increased only 1-1/4 percent. This pace likely understates the underlying momentum in aggregate demand, in part because of a sizable inventory correction that began early last year;', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The combination of strong job gains and mediocre GDP growth has resulted in exceptionally slow labor productivity growth. Most recently, business-sector productivity is reported to have declined for the past three quarters, its worst performance since 1979.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A 1-1/4 percentage point slowdown in productivity growth is a massive change, one that, if it were to persist, would have wide-ranging consequences for employment, wage growth, and economic policy more broadly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Let me highlight a few topics from the growing volume of research on this topic. The first is that the productivity slowdown reflects mismeasurement, because the official statistics have failed to capture new and better products or properly account for changes in prices over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Rather, the key to boosting productivity growth, and the long-run potential of the economy, is more likely to be found in effective fiscal and regulatory policies. While there is disagreement about what the most effective policies would be, some combination of improved public infrastructure, better education, more encouragement for private investment, and more-effective regulation all likely have a role to play.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I am grateful to Christopher Nekarda, Joseph Gruber, David Lebow, and Stacey Tevlin of the Federal Reserve Board staff for their assistance. Views expressed are mine and are not necessarily those of the Federal Reserve Board or the Federal Open Market Committee.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='See Carmen M. Reinhart and Kenneth S. Rogoff (2009), This Time Is Different: Eight Centuries of Financial Folly (Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press).', theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Having been given the privilege of opening this conference, let me start at the very beginning with the term "shadow banking." The very phrase evokes the sense of something hidden, furtive even--a sort of film noir backdrop for extending credit, in contrast to the well-lit setting of the local insured depository institution.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Damaging as these arrangements were, however, they do not define the range of issues associated with the term shadow banking. A broader definition would embrace all forms of lending outside of prudentially regulated institutions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Rather than dwell on definitions, much less attempt to develop a taxonomy of shadow banking, I think it more productive to focus on the characteristics of shadow banking-related financial activities and institutions that are most likely to pose risks to financial stability and to the economy more generally.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The difference, of course, was that the run was not principally on depository institutions, as in the 1930s, but on asset-backed commercial paper programs, broker-dealers, money market funds, and other intermediaries that were heavily dependent on short-term wholesale funding.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Runs and panics are the defining characteristic of a financial crisis, transforming debt problems that might themselves have produced a drag on the economy into a classic adverse feedback loop with more devastating consequences.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Thus, in deciding where--from a prudential viewpoint--to concentrate analysis and policy initiatives within the broad universe of activities that can be described by the term shadow banking, it seems to me that the presence of runnable funding is the key, though perhaps not the only consideration.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But just because the levels of runnable funding are significantly lower than before the crisis does not necessarily mean they are at safe or optimal levels. And it seems quite reasonable to expect that new forms of financial intermediation based substantially on runnable funding could develop in the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, to what degree will it rely on uniform regulation of users of runnable funding no matter what the characteristics of the market actors and business models involved in the funding relationship?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, what agency or agencies would be the appropriate regulators? The answer to this question would obviously be related to the answer to the first, though some different considerations do apply.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Third, what form or forms would the regulation take?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fourth, as a factual matter, to what extent is the supply of short-term funding a response to a persistent demand for more safe assets?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='And so, fifth, to what extent does a comprehensive regulatory approach to shadow banking need to include mechanisms--involving the government directly or indirectly--for the creation of more genuinely safe assets, as well as limitations on the runnable varieties that can precipitate or exacerbate financial stress?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There are the questions.', theme='other')]

title: Recent Economic Developments, Monetary Policy Considerations and Longer-term Prospects
speaker: Governor Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The chairman notes that job growth has been stronger than expected since 2011, with unemployment declining faster than forecasted.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, economic growth has been consistently lower than forecasted, including by Federal Reserve officials.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The chairman observes that the current recovery has been slower than many previous recoveries...', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...and cites research showing that weak recoveries are common after deep recessions and those associated with severe financial crises.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The chairman expresses concern about slow productivity growth since 2000, which he attributes to a decline in economic dynamism.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...He notes that the birthrate of startups has been declining since the 1970s, and that labor market fluidity has also declined. This, in turn, may be contributing to slower productivity growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The chairman mentions occupational licensing as one possible contributor to reduced job and worker reallocation...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...citing research suggesting that licensing requirements have become overly burdensome.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The chairman notes that monetary policy will need to remain supportive of growth in a challenging global environment.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='...He also emphasizes the importance of careful monitoring of economic developments to assess the stance of policy.', theme='other')]

title: Comments on the Resolution Framework for Banks and Bank Holding Companies in the United States
speaker: Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="I'm grateful to the organizers for inviting me to participate in this conference.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='U.S. law provides several legal frameworks for resolving failed financial firms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the Federal Deposit Insurance Act creates a special resolution framework for failed banks, a failed U.S. bank holding company--that is, a corporate entity that controls one or more banks--would generally be resolved under the same provisions of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code as would apply to other corporate debtors, such as industrial firms, in a proceeding overseen by a federal judge.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To increase the viability of the Bankruptcy Code as a framework for resolving failed financial firms without major systemic consequences, section 165(d) of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 (Dodd-Frank Act) requires large banking organizations to produce resolution plans, also known as living wills, demonstrating how they could be resolved under the Bankruptcy Code in an orderly fashion in the event of failure.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although the Bankruptcy Code provides the default legal framework for the resolution of a failed bank holding company, Title II of the Dodd-Frank Act creates a backup resolution framework, called the orderly liquidation authority, to be used if the resolution of a failed financial company under the Bankruptcy Code would have serious adverse effects on U.S. financial stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve Board has recently proposed important new rules to increase the prospects for the orderly resolution of a GSIB with minimal effect on financial stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The proposal would also apply internal TLAC and long-term debt requirements to the U.S. intermediate holding companies of foreign GSIBs in order to facilitate the recapitalization of a failed foreign GSIB's U.S. operations.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In May of this year, the Board issued another proposal to make GSIBs more resolvable.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although the Bankruptcy Code provides an adequate framework for the resolution of any financial company, Title II of the Dodd-Frank Act recognizes that the Bankruptcy Code may not be adequate to minimize the systemic impact of the resolution of a systemically important financial firm.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="However, under the Board's proposed TLAC rule, a failed GSIB would be recapitalized by its private-sector long-term creditors (whose debt claims would be converted into equity), not by the government.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I also note that credit rating agencies have recognized public-sector efforts to end the too-big-to-fail phenomenon.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The existence of a thick tranche of loss-absorbing long-term debt should reduce a GSIB's probability of failure by reducing its short-term creditors' incentives to run at the first sign of distress.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In short, we and other U.S. regulators are working hard to address the too-big-to-fail problem by improving the prospects for the orderly resolution of a GSIB in the United States.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The average (per bank) assets of the 465 banks resolved by the FDIC between 2008 and 2012 was roughly $1.5 billion, with a total of $680.3 billion.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Lehman's pre-bankruptcy total assets were $691 billion.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Under the proposal, a U.S. GSIB would be subject to external long-term debt requirements of 6 percent of risk-weighted assets plus the amount of the risk-based capital surcharge applicable to the GSIB under the Board's GSIB surcharge rule and 4.5 percent of total leverage exposure.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='See Board of Governors (2015), "Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity, Long-Term Debt, and Clean Holding Company Requirements," in note 5.', theme='other')]

title: Introductory Comments
speaker: Governor Jerome H. Powell
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='I want to thank you all for coming today, and I also want to thank the Alternative Reference Rates Committee (ARRC) for all its work in developing its interim report.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In saying this, I want to make it clear that LIBOR has been significantly improved.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That basic fact poses the risk that LIBOR could eventually be forced to stop publication entirely.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These concerns led the FSB and Financial Stability Oversight Council to call for the promotion of alternatives to LIBOR, and led the Federal Reserve to convene the ARRC in cooperation with the U.S. Treasury Department, U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and Office of Financial Research.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="We need input from end users and others to finalize the ARRC's plans, and I look forward to hearing the views of those in attendance.", theme='other')]

title: Current Conditions and the Outlook for the U.S. Economy
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Yellen notes that productivity growth in the United States has been slower than expected, averaging about 1% per year since the Great Recession.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Despite slow productivity growth, the labor market has continued to improve, with the unemployment rate falling and wages growing modestly.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Yellen discusses how low inflation can be a problem for monetary policy, making it difficult to push interest rates down further in response to economic shocks.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Chair notes that the Federal Reserve is monitoring these trends carefully, considering how they might affect future monetary policy decisions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Yellen emphasizes that the Fed's policies are not on a 'preset course' and that the Committee will respond to new data and reassess risks as necessary.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='"The recent slowdown in productivity growth has been a significant surprise."', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='"Low inflation can be too low, especially when it is accompanied by small-than-anticipated nominal income gains."', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='"Monetary policy is not on a preset course, and the Committee will respond to new data and reassess risks as necessary."', theme='other')]

title: The Economic Outlook and Implications for Monetary Policy
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Yellen begins by discussing the economic outlook and notes that the US economy has been growing at a moderate pace since the Great Recession. However, she also highlights several risks to this growth, including:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Global economic risks**: Yellen notes that global economic conditions have been volatile in recent years, with declines in commodity prices, slowing growth in emerging markets, and potential risks from Brexit.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Labor market challenges**: She points out that while the labor market has been improving, there are still challenges ahead, including a shrinking labor force participation rate and slow wage growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Financial stability risks**: Yellen notes that financial conditions have tightened recently, with lower asset prices and higher borrowing costs.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Yellen discusses the role of monetary policy in addressing these economic risks. She notes that the Federal Reserve has kept interest rates low to support the economy during this period of slow growth. However, she also cautions that the Fed must balance its desire to promote growth with the need to maintain financial stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Yellen discusses the concept of the "neutral" or "natural" interest rate, which is the level at which the economy can grow without generating inflationary pressures. She notes that this rate may be lower than previously thought due to structural changes in the economy, such as a decline in labor force participation and slower productivity growth.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Yellen concludes by noting that the Fed will continue to carefully monitor economic conditions and make adjustments to monetary policy as necessary. However, she also cautions that the path ahead may be more gradual than previously anticipated due to the need for a shallow and sustained recovery.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* US GDP growth has been averaging around 2-1/2% per year since the Great Recession.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Labor force participation rate has declined by about 3 percentage points since 2007.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Productivity growth has slowed to an average annual gain of just 1.1% since 2007.', theme='other')]

title: Insurance Companies and the Role of the Federal Reserve
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The document discusses two key approaches to setting capital requirements for insurance companies:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, the CA is more appropriate for systemically important insurance companies, which pose significant risks to financial stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For systemically important insurance companies, the CA would take a more integrated approach to setting capital requirements, using consolidated financial information based on U.S. GAAP.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The document concludes that a bifurcated approach to capital requirements for insurance companies makes sense, with different approaches for insurance companies owning banks and those designated as systemically important.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve will issue an Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPR) to solicit comments from stakeholders on this approach before developing and proposing its details.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This document provides a detailed analysis of the key issues and potential approaches to setting capital requirements for insurance companies, with a focus on mitigating systemic risks and ensuring safety and soundness.', theme='other')]

title: (Money), Interest and Prices: Patinkin and Woodford
speaker: Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Harry G. Johnson's 1962 paper 'Monetary Theory and Policy' has been influential in monetary economics. However, his criticism of Don Patinkin's 'Money, Interest, and Prices' did not hold up.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Neo-Wicksellian approach, which is based on the work of Knut Wicksell, focuses on the relationship between real interest rates and the natural rate of interest. This approach has become dominant in monetary policy analysis. The natural rate of interest is an equilibrium concept that represents the level of interest rates at which there is no tendency for output or inflation to change.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve's use of DSGE (Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium) models has led to estimates of the natural rate of interest that have been volatile and hard to measure. However, researchers have developed more realistic features in these models, such as important roles for financial frictions, which fit the data better and bear some resemblance to traditional output gap estimates.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Fed's research has shown that estimating the natural rate is difficult, but estimates indicate it fell considerably during the financial crisis and became negative in its aftermath. An alternative concept, the equilibrium rate of interest, has also played an important role in policy discussions.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Michael Woodford's work on monetary theory and policy has had a significant impact on Fed thinking and analysis, particularly through his neo-Wicksellian analysis of monetary policy. His ideas have been influential in shaping the Fed's understanding of the relationship between output and inflation around their natural values and economic welfare.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve's researchers, including over a dozen Woodford students, have attempted to measure the natural rates of interest and output gaps using DSGE models. Early work produced volatile estimates, leading to the development of more realistic features in these models. The Fed now uses DSGE models routinely in monetary policy discussions.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One key lesson from these models is that measuring the natural rate of interest or the output gap is challenging. Estimates of the natural rate of interest are closely tied to the structure of the DSGE models and ignore long-term structural changes in the balance between saving and investment. Therefore, an alternative concept, the equilibrium rate of interest, has also played a significant role in policy discussions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Researchers aim to develop improved estimates of the long-run equilibrium interest rate and develop policies that can influence it. In this context, faster trend growth would increase the long-run equilibrium interest rate, which is critical for the future of the United States and global economies.', theme='employment')]

title: The Use of Distributed Ledger Technologies in Payment, Clearing, and Settlement
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Innovation in digital finance, loosely referred to as fintech, is capturing imaginations from Silicon Valley to Chicago to Wall Street. We're seeing a steady stream of announcements of new startups and partnerships, and consumers are downloading fintech apps at an even faster pace.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Financial products, services, and transactions lend themselves to successive waves of technological disruption because they can readily be represented as streams of numerical information ripe for digitization. However, as technological tools used by the industry change over time, it is important to keep sight of their impact on the public, whether it be on families seeking to own their own home, seniors seeking financial security, young adults seeking to invest in education and training, or small businesses attempting to smooth through volatile revenues and expenses.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Current developments in the digitization of finance are important and deserving of serious and sustained engagement on the part of policymakers and regulators. The Federal Reserve Board has established a multi-disciplinary working group that is engaged in a 360-degree analysis of fintech innovation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Technological and Organizational Changes in Payment, Clearing, and Settlement\xa0Today, I will focus on newly emerging distributed ledger technologies and related protocols, which were inspired originally by Bitcoin, and their potentially important applications to payment, clearing, and settlement in the wholesale markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Successive waves of technological advance have swept through payment, clearing, and settlement over the past two centuries. In the 19th century, railroads and the telegraph helped improve the speed and efficiency of payment processing.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The distributed ledger technology is expected to increase the speed and efficiency of payment processing, making it easier for consumers to make payments and for businesses to receive payments.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Moreover, distributed ledgers will have to compete with other options and priorities of financial firms and clearinghouses in a highly regulated financial ecosystem. Thus, a major threshold question for the adoption of distributed ledger technology within and between groups of firms engaging in particular types of transactions is whether the advantages outweigh the costs of replacing legacy systems.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Safety and integrity in clearing and settlement is a critical, long-standing public policy objective of the Federal Reserve, and is critical for broader financial stability. Regardless of the technologies employed, if risks to clearing and settlement are not identified and addressed, then banks, dealers, and other firms will not be able to manage their obligations and market functioning may be impaired.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Digital ledger technologies will need to be able to address the range of issues revolving around the confidentiality and security of firm and client records and data on the one hand, as well as law enforcement requirements and issues on the other. New technologies must be robust in practice, not just in theory, to attacks on security, and must be able to maintain appropriate confidentiality for records and data.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The key challenges going forward will include scaling distributed ledger technology, interoperating with legacy systems, managing access rights, balancing privacy and settlement efficiency, developing sound risk-management procedures, and ensuring the safety and integrity of clearing and settlement functions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In conclusion, central bankers and markets have learned through hard lessons over many years that the daily operation of markets and their clearing and settlement functions are built on trust and confidence. Market participants trust that clearing and settlement functions and institutions will work properly every day.', theme='other')]

title: The Outlook, Uncertainty, and Monetary Policy
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed has revised down its growth forecast for 2016 and 2017 due to slower-than-expected economic expansion. Despite this, unemployment rates are expected to remain low, and inflation is still projected to reach 2% in the long run.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Revised growth forecast**: The Fed has lowered its growth projections for 2016 and 2017 by 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Inflation prospects**: Despite slower-than-expected economic expansion, inflation is still expected to reach 2% in the long run.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Neutral interest rate**: The neutral interest rate, which is the interest rate consistent with maximum employment and stable prices, is estimated to be near zero due to low unemployment rates and suppressed wage growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Monetary policy implications**: Given the effective lower bound on nominal interest rates (i.e., the 0% lower bound), the Fed should exercise greater gradualism when implementing monetary policies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Unconventional policies**: The Fed could use unconventional tools, such as resuming large-scale purchases of Treasury securities or agency mortgage-backed securities, to further stimulate economic growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The speech mentions several academic papers and research studies that support these conclusions. It also references the Fed's Summary of Economic Projections (SEP) released in March 2016, which revised down its growth forecast for 2016 and 2017.", theme='other')]

speaker: Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The author also discusses various economic theories and models, including:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Secular Stagnation**: A prolonged period of low output growth due to insufficient aggregate demand or low productivity growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Effective Lower Bound (ELB)**: The minimum interest rate that can be set by a central bank without causing inflationary pressures.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Phillips Curve**: A trade-off between unemployment and inflation, where lower unemployment is associated with higher inflation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="4. **Okun's Law**: An empirical relationship between the output gap (the difference between actual and potential GDP) and the unemployment gap.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="5. **Monetary Policy**: The central bank's actions to manage interest rates and inflation, influenced by the ELB.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **IS Curve**: A graphical representation of the relationship between output and interest rates.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Loan Market Equation**: A model describing the supply and demand for loans in the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Uncovered Interest Rate Parity**: An equation equating domestic and foreign interest rates, adjusted for exchange rate changes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. Robert Merton (no direct reference)', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. James Tobin', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. Michael Woodford', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, this paper provides an in-depth analysis of economic concepts and models relevant to monetary policy decisions, particularly in times of low inflation and the effective lower bound.', theme='inflation')]

title: An Update on the Outlook, Liquidity, and Resilience
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The speaker highlights several key points:', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Monetary Policy Path**: The Fed should continue to normalize monetary policy, given that inflation remains below target.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Inflation Expectations**: Inflation expectations remain well-anchored, and the speaker notes that recent increases in core PCE prices may be due to transitory factors.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Long-term Interest Rates**: Long-term interest rates have remained low, partly due to a decline in the natural rate of interest.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **Corporate Bond Market Liquidity**: The speaker expresses concerns about the liquidity of corporate bond markets, citing research that suggests herding behavior among institutional investors.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Neutral Rate**: The neutral rate of interest has fallen, which may weigh on the policy path.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **Normalizing Monetary Policy**: The Fed should continue to normalize monetary policy, given that inflation remains below target.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech also mentions several research papers and articles by various authors, including Tobias Adrian, Michael Fleming, Lael Brainard, Olivier Blanchard, and others.', theme='other')]

title: What Happened to the Great Divergence?
speaker: Governor Lael Brainard
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech discusses the state of global economic growth, pointing out that it remains anemic despite some improvements.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Brainard notes that while there have been some gains in employment and consumer confidence, wages are still slow to rise, part-time work is higher than before the Great Recession, and productivity growth has slowed significantly.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Brainard suggests that the slope of the Phillips curve in the U.S. has declined substantially since the 1970s, implying that any given level of unemployment is associated with lower inflation than was the case decades ago.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This context influences monetary policy decisions worldwide.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='She discusses the concept of the "neutral" or "equilibrium real interest rate," which is the rate at which the economy is expected to grow without being influenced by monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governor Brainard stresses the importance of considering how economic conditions and policies in one country can affect others through global trade and financial linkages.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In light of these considerations, the speech advocates for a coordinated approach to monetary policy when dealing with common challenges or spillover effects across borders.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It also suggests that under certain conditions, cooperation among central banks could be beneficial, particularly in communicating policies that address global issues and boost confidence.', theme='other')]

title: Recent Monetary Policy Developments
speaker: Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='I am a macroeconomist, and do not plan on focusing tonight on developments in the energy sector. But from time to time the price of oil becomes a macroeconomic issue, and this is one of those times.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you all know, at our December meeting the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/4 percentage point, to 1/4 to 1/2 percent.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Our decision in December was based on the substantial improvement in the labor market and the Committee's confidence that inflation would return to our 2 percent goal over the medium term.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, global financial markets have been unusually volatile since the turn of the year. For instance, the S&P 500 volatility index (VIX) rose markedly in early January, though it remains below the levels it reached in August of last year and in 2011.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If the recent financial market developments lead to a sustained tightening of financial conditions, they could signal a slowing in the global economy that could affect growth and inflation in the United States.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Now, with our next FOMC meeting just three weeks away, I expect most of you are less interested in what we did at our previous meetings, and more interested in what we are going to do at the next one.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, most estimates of the full employment rate of unemployment are close to 5 percent. The actual rate of unemployment is now slightly below 5 percent, and the median view of the members of the FOMC is that it will decline further.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The second issue is how best to integrate balance sheet policy with interest rate policy. The FOMC has indicated that the Federal Reserve will, in the longer run, hold no more securities than necessary to implement monetary policy efficiently and effectively.', theme='other')]

title: Recent Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='As you all know, at our December meeting my colleagues and I on the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate by 1/4 percentage point, to 1/4 to 1/2 percent.2 This increase came after seven years during which we kept the federal funds rate at what we call the ELB--the effective lower bound. This ultra-low rate was in keeping with our congressional mandate to pursue a monetary policy that fosters maximum employment and price stability, which we define as 2 percent inflation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Our decision in December was based on the substantial improvement in the labor market and the Committee's confidence that inflation would return to our 2 percent goal over the medium term. Employment growth last year averaged a solid 220,000 per month, and the unemployment rate declined from 5.6 percent to 5.0 percent over the course of 2015.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation ran well below our target last year, held down by the transitory effects of declines in crude oil prices and also in the prices of non-oil imports. Prices for these goods have fallen further and for longer than expected.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Once these oil and import prices stop falling and level out, their effects on inflation will dissipate, which is why we expect that inflation will rise to 2 percent over the medium term, supported by a further strengthening in labor market conditions.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Given the large size of the Federal Reserve's balance sheet, the FOMC is employing new tools to implement monetary policy. In particular, to raise the federal funds rate we increased the interest rate we pay on reserve balances that depository institutions hold at the Federal Reserve.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='At our meeting last week, we left our target for the federal funds rate unchanged. Economic data over the intermeeting period suggested that improvement in labor market conditions continued even as economic growth slowed late last year.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But further declines in oil prices and increases in the foreign exchange value of the dollar suggested that inflation would likely remain low for somewhat longer than had been previously expected before moving back to 2 percent.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Now, I expect that in a few minutes one of you will ask not about what we did at our last meeting, but rather what we are going to do at the next one. I can't answer that question because, as I have emphasized in the past, we simply do not know.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That is why the Committee has indicated that its policy decisions will be data dependent. That is, we will adjust policy appropriately in light of economic and financial events to best foster conditions consistent with the attainment of our employment and inflation objectives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you know, in making our policy decisions, my FOMC colleagues and I spend considerable time assessing the incoming economic and financial information and its implications for the economic outlook. title: Nonbank Financial Intermediation, Financial Stability, and the Road Forward
speaker: Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='The nonbank financial sector has undergone significant changes and reforms since the 2008 global financial crisis, but there is still more work to be done to ensure stability.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Key Areas for Reform:**

1. **Securitization reform**: A new regulation requires securitizers to retain some of the risk of the securities they create.
2. **Derivative reforms**: Reforms aim to reduce complexity and pro-cyclicality by moving standardized derivatives to central counterparties (CCPs) and requiring initial and variation margin for noncleared derivatives.
3. **Money market mutual fund rules**: New rules require prime institutional money funds to publish a floating net asset value rather than a stable value of $1 per unit.
4. **Data collection**: The Office of Financial Research has collected data on hedge funds, repurchase agreements, and securities lending.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Challenges Ahead:**

1. **Increased complexity**: Stronger regulation of the banking sector may lead to greater complexity in nonbank activities.
2. **Migration of risk**: Nonbanks may move their activities outside traditional regulatory perimeters, making monitoring and oversight more challenging.
3. **Risk of runs**: Some nonbank firms are still vulnerable to runs on their assets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Recommendations:**

1. **Close monitoring**: Authorities should closely monitor the system for changes that increase systemic risk.
2. **Adaptation of regulations**: Regulations should be adapted as necessary to address emerging threats and maintain stability.
3. **International cooperation**: International cooperation is crucial in addressing global financial risks and promoting a stable financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Conclusion:**

While progress has been made in strengthening prudential regulation and supervision of the nonbank financial sector, more work remains to ensure long-term stability. Vigilance is required to identify emerging threats and adapt regulations as necessary.', theme='other')]

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='I would like to thank the Banque de France for inviting me to take part in what I expect will be a lively discussion.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The suddenness and severity of the global financial crisis forced policymakers to respond rapidly and creatively, employing a wide range of macroeconomic tools--including both monetary and fiscal policies--to arrest a steep economic downturn and restart the global economy. Given the slow and unsteady nature of the recovery, supportive policy remains necessary.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Prior to the global financial crisis, inflation rates in the United States and other advanced economies were near their target levels and most of these economies appeared to be operating close to their potential. Policy interest rates were similarly in the vicinity of levels considered to be normal.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Fiscal deficits also appeared to be under control before the crisis. According to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), general government deficits in 2007 were less than 4 percent of GDP in the United States and the United Kingdom, about 2 percent in Japan, and less than 1 percent, on average, in the euro area.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When the crisis hit, its global scope and severity were exceptional. Central banks in the United States and other countries responded by rapidly and sharply reducing their policy interest rates, lowering them in many cases to near zero.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Initially, fiscal policy also provided significant stimulus. A portion of this stimulus reflected the operation of automatic stabilizers--higher unemployment benefits, for example, and some came through cuts in tax rates and increases in discretionary spending.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The combination of increasing debt and depressed output led to rising ratios of debt to gross domestic product (GDP) in many advanced economies and heightened concern about whether the growth in debt could be sustained without unsettling financial markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With fiscal drag weighing on growth and with private-sector deleveraging also holding back consumption and investment, monetary policy bore the brunt of supporting the economy. With policy rates at or approaching zero, central banks of necessity turned to unconventional policy tools such as large-scale asset purchases and enhanced forward guidance about the future path of policy rates.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Even so, the recovery in most advanced nations has proceeded more slowly than policymakers would have hoped. This sluggishness has been due in part to the severity of the financial shock associated with the crisis and the persistent headwinds to recovery in its aftermath.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='What lessons can we draw from this experience? The first is that governments need to address long-term challenges and significantly improve their structural fiscal balances during good times so they have more fiscal space to provide stimulus when times turn bad.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A second lesson is that, while even if it is appropriate for fiscal policy to play a larger role when policy rates are near zero, policymakers nevertheless may face constraints in implementing fiscal stimulus. This means that central banks need to be prepared to employ all available tools, including unconventional policies, to support economic growth and to reach their inflation targets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A third critical lesson pertains to the importance of having a sound and resilient financial sector with strong capitalization and prudent risk management, supported by effective regulation and supervision.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In advanced economies, the current macroeconomic policy mix generally remains one of extraordinary monetary policy stimulus and somewhat contractionary fiscal policy. Considering the headwinds that continue to weigh on growth, employment, and prices, this situation is hardly ideal.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Even so, I continue to anticipate that the headwinds associated with the financial crisis will wane. As employment, economic activity, and inflation rates return to normal, monetary policy will eventually need to normalize too, although the speed and timing of this normalization will likely differ across countries based on differences in the pace of recovery in domestic conditions.', theme='employment')]

title: Small Businesses and the Recovery
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='After the onset of the crisis, the Federal Reserve took extraordinary steps to stabilize the financial system and halt the plunge in economic activity. Since then, the Fed has continued to use its monetary policy tools to promote the recovery and make progress toward our mandated objectives of maximum employment and price stability. By putting downward pressure on interest rates, the Fed is trying to make financial conditions more accommodative--supporting asset values and lower borrowing costs for households and businesses and thus encouraging the spending that spurs job creation and a stronger recovery.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Crucial to this process, as I just mentioned, is job creation. The Federal Reserve tries to promote the conditions to foster job creation, but, overwhelmingly, it is businesses that create the jobs. About 85 percent of nonfarm employment is in the private sector, which traditionally is the source of a similarly large share of new jobs during economic expansions. So far during this expansion, public-sector employment has declined and the private sector has accounted for all of the net increase in employment, so businesses have been even more crucial to job creation than usual.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Small businesses, of course, are responsible for a large share of these new jobs. According to the latest data from the Labor Department, a little more than half of the net number of jobs created since employment began growing in 2010 has been generated by firms with fewer than 250 employees, and most of that amount was accounted for by firms with fewer than 50 employees.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One of the reasons I wanted so much to be here this evening was to be able to acknowledge these important contributions. America has come a long way since the dark days of the financial crisis, and small businesses deserve a considerable share of the credit for the investment and hiring that have brought that progress.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I am honored to be addressing the owners of 53 small businesses whose excellence exemplifies the enormous contributions that millions of small businesses collectively make to our economy. You come from different places and have achieved success in a wide variety of ways, but you all share the entrepreneurial spirit that has always been central to our nation's prosperity.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Thank you.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. See Bureau of Labor Statistics (2014), "Business Employment Dynamics: Third Quarter 2013," press release, April 29.', theme='other')]

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Many of these issues, of course, are ones the FMC has grappled with every year since the crisis, an event which elevated the importance of this gathering and of the vital contributions made by the research and the policy discussion the FMC fosters.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One of those issues is liquidity. Maturity transformation is a central part of the economic function of banks and many other types of financial intermediaries. But as we saw in the crisis, maturity transformation also exposes intermediaries to liquidity risk, particularly when intermediaries are heavily reliant on short-term wholesale funding.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Strong bank capital rules remain the foundation of bank regulation. But capital requirements as currently constructed are generally based on credit and market risks from the asset side of the balance sheet and from off-balance-sheet transactions. They do not directly address liquidity risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Thus, the Basel Committee's second task was to develop new liquidity standards for global banking firms: the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) and the Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR).", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As others have observed, the new Basel liquidity standards address financial stability risks associated with excessive maturity transformation through at least two channels.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, the new standards insulate banks from liquidity shocks. In the case of the LCR, requiring firms to hold a buffer of highly liquid assets will help to ensure that they have a means of generating liquidity in the event of creditor runs.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, the new standards provide an incentive for firms to move to more stable funding structures. Under the LCR and NSFR, firms that engage in unstable forms of maturity transformation will be required to maintain buffers of highly liquid assets and use stable funding, both of which will impose costs for the firms.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the LCR and NSFR are important steps forward, they do not fully address the financial stability concerns associated with short-term wholesale funding.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Federal Reserve staff are actively considering additional measures that could address these and other residual risks in the short-term wholesale funding markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While it would be a mistake to give undue weight to any one study, this study provides some support for the view that there might be room for stronger capital and liquidity standards for large banks than have been adopted so far.', theme='other')]

title: Remarks on Women's History Month
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It's an honor and a pleasure for me to be here with you to mark Women's History Month, which itself has some history behind it.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="March 8, 1911 was the first International Women's Day, and it was 1980 when President Carter established National Women's History Week. In 1987, Congress acted to make that week a full month.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Women, of course, are also a part of history for the other 11 months of the year. And I would add that women were influencing the course of history long before 1980, or 1911. But I am glad that there is, each year, a time when we pause to think about the role of women, because history is more than simply what happened, and more than what women and men did to make it happen.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='History is what we remember about those deeds. It is the lessons we have taken from the past and the knowledge we draw on to live today and to shape the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For me, one lesson from history is that it is no coincidence that America\'s great success in the past century came as women steadily increased their participation in every aspect of society. Starting with gaining the vote, just a few years before International Women\'s Day, "The American Century," as it\'s sometimes known, was also a century of progress for women.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Fundamental to our country's values, to those ideals that have been and continue to be so influential around the world, is the principle of equality for all, including for women.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="One reason America's example is influential elsewhere is because progress toward these ideals has been accompanied by great success in broadly raising living standards. And I think our economic success has been due in substantial part to the fuller participation and contribution of women to the economy.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Their increasing participation in the workforce, particularly after 1970, was a major factor in sustaining growing family incomes. Making fuller use of the talents and efforts of women in the workplace has made us more productive and prosperous.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='If I were to apply this lesson, I would hope that our nation continues to reap the benefits of greater participation by women in the economy and that we do everything that we can to foster that participation. Women have made great progress in many occupations and professions, but lag in others.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In my own profession, there has been a gradual increase in the share of women in economics, but women still remain underrepresented at the highest levels in academia, in government and in business. There are doubtless numerous reasons for this, and in fact economists themselves are among those engaged in trying to understand the factors that explain why more women aren't rising to higher levels.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I hope we continue to seek this understanding, in my field and others where women are in the minority, because the benefits of greater participation for women, it seems to me, are clear and substantial.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As we continue to make progress in recovering from the Great Recession, our country is going to need the best efforts, ideas and talent it can muster to succeed in an increasingly competitive global economy. If women's history can shape the future, I hope that it inspires America to take those steps we can take to draw forth these contributions from all Americans.", theme='employment')]

title: Welcoming Remarks
speaker: Governor Jeremy C. Stein
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Today's topic of crowdfunding for community development finance is an important and topical one, and I want to thank you all for helping us think through the challenges and opportunities presented by this new technology as it relates to raising funds for local communities.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This gathering is particularly timely for two reasons. First, in many communities, traditional resources for community development are shrinking, and the field is actively seeking to identify new sources of funding. Second, the Securities and Exchange Commission recently released its proposed rule under the Jumpstart Our Business Startups--or JOBS--Act, which is likely to influence the environment for crowdfunding in general and for community development finance specifically.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To the extent that most people know about crowdfunding at all, they may associate it with tech startups or independent movie production, since the press coverage has often focused on examples in these areas. These stories typically describe the use, and often success, of crowdfunding, as aspiring inventors and artists are able to tap the Internet to raise the money that can help make their visions a reality.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The question for today is whether this power of the crowd can be harnessed to support community development, a field that has not widely benefitted from crowdfunding thus far. Indeed, when I say 'power of the crowd,' it is worth noting that while individual investment amounts may be small, the total amount of funds raised from this source can be large.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Although we lack reliable data on the current size of crowdfunding, some sources indicate that it's a multibillion-dollar industry, with more than 1 million separate offerings each year, and that the field is growing rapidly.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While crowdfunding may not be as well known in the community development context, there are, in fact, existing models of crowdfunding for community development that we can learn from. I understand that several of these existing models will be discussed on a panel later this morning.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One local example is Fundrise, an investment platform for commercial real estate that gives individuals the opportunity to invest directly in neighborhood businesses. Fundrise started on the H Street corridor here in D.C., and has completed 18 real estate deals totaling more than $10 million.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For example, this platform attracted 361 people to invest a total of $350,000 toward the redevelopment of 906 H Street, N.E. Currently a vacant building, this property, which is located on the quickly revitalizing H Street corridor, now has the funding necessary to renovate the property and transform it into a restaurant or retail space.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="A second example is Calvert Foundation's Community Investment Note. This is an interesting one because Calvert Foundation was essentially doing something akin to crowdfunding for community development before Internet platforms became available.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='According to Calvert Foundation, these 13,000 individual investments have collectively helped to create 430,000 jobs for low-income individuals, built or rehabilitated 17,000 affordable homes, and financed close to 26,000 nonprofit facilities and social enterprises.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Many of you may be wondering, 'Why is the Fed interested in this topic?' First, at a fundamental level, it's important for us to keep our finger on the pulse of financial innovation and the changing dynamics of the financial services industry--even in those parts of the industry where we do not have a direct regulatory role.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We know that financial innovation can offer both opportunities and pitfalls; by carefully and even-handedly studying each new product or service at an early stage in its lifecycle, we can hope to better understand both the potential benefits, as well as any risks for adverse impacts on households and communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Also, through convenings like today's event and by sharing promising practices, the Federal Reserve System has a longstanding history of supporting local and regional community and economic development efforts that contribute to economic growth and employment.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As I mentioned earlier, many people associate crowdfunding with tech startups and art initiatives. However, there may be ways that this new form of fundraising can be adapted to community development investing.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Given how wide open the issues are, today's event is a working meeting with discussion groups. We appreciate your willingness to share your time with us, and we look forward to benefitting from your insights.", theme='other')]

title: Remarks at the Ceremonial Swearing-in
speaker: Chair Janet L. Yellen

title: Opening Remarks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve's extraordinary response to the financial crisis and the Great Recession that followed was, in one sense, nothing new. We did what central banks have done for many years and what they were designed to do: We served as a source of liquidity and stability in financial markets, and, in the broader economy, we worked to foster economic recovery and price stability.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When the financial system teetered near collapse in 2008 and 2009, we responded as the 19th century British essayist Walter Bagehot advised, by serving as liquidity provider of last resort to stressed financial firms and markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Beyond the provision of liquidity, the Fed worked with other agencies both here and abroad to help restore public confidence in the financial system. Notably, we led the development of stress-testing large banking organizations' capital adequacy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed has also worked to draw the appropriate lessons from the crisis and to take the steps necessary to help avoid a similar event in the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have also had to be innovative in finding ways to use monetary policy to help the economy recover from the deep recession that followed the crisis.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A significant aspect of finding innovative ways to execute our duties as a central bank in a new, more complex environment has been the ongoing revolution in communication and transparency.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In summary, the financial crisis that the Fed confronted five years ago was in many ways analogous to the panics that central banks have faced for centuries. But, at the same time, the crisis and the deep recession that followed occurred in an economic and financial environment that was certainly different, and in many ways more complex, than in the past.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One of my personal objectives since I became Chairman has been to increase the transparency of the Fed--to more clearly explain how our policies are intended to work and the thinking behind our decisions.', theme='other')]

title: Concluding Remarks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Among the Fed's most important values is the belief that policymaking should be based on dispassionate, objective, and fact-based analysis.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Of course, policy analysis and implementation of the highest quality do not just happen. But one value that strikes me as having been at least as important as any other has been the Federal Reserve's willingness, during its finest hours, to stand up to political pressure and make tough but necessary decisions.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We have been able to respond nimbly to economic emergencies and make difficult choices in part because of our institutional structure--including long terms for members of the Board of Governors and diverse regional representation in our policymaking Committee--and because of the willingness of policymakers, past and present, to do whatever was needed in the longer-run interest of the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="But, finally, we must also recognize that the Fed's ability to make and implement such decisions ultimately depends on the public's understanding and acceptance of our actions. title: Teaching and Learning about the Federal Reserve
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Thank you for that introduction. Tonight marks the third time in just a little over three years that the Federal Reserve System has hosted a teacher town hall, and I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak with educators, both those of you here in Washington, D.C., and those watching at Reserve Bank gatherings around the country. I look forward to your questions in a few moments. But let me begin by briefly discussing an important milestone for the Federal Reserve--its centennial--and the opportunity that this occasion affords to teach and learn about the Fed's origins, history, and role, and about how this institution has helped shape the nation's economy and financial system.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="President Woodrow Wilson signed the Federal Reserve Act, which established the Federal Reserve System, on December 23, 1913. As the 100th anniversary of that event approaches, we have several reasons to look back at an eventful century. One important reason is to better understand what historical experience can teach us about how best to respond to current challenges. For example, as many of you know, the bold measures the Fed took in response to the recent financial crisis reflected in part its determination to avoid repeating the sorts of mistakes it made before and during the Great Depression of the 1930s. Similarly, our commitment to safeguarding price stability is reinforced by memories of the costs of high inflation during the 1970s and the Federal Reserve's subsequent restoration of price stability under Chairman Volcker during the 1980s.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Beyond the insights that the study of the Federal Reserve's first 100 years offer to economists, historians, and policymakers about how the Fed can best meet its objectives today and in the future, a second reason to mark the centennial is the opportunity it affords to educate young people about the Federal Reserve and its important role in promoting a healthy economy and stable financial system.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Economics also complements and enriches the study of history. When I took history classes in high school, we spent much of our time memorizing dates and important events--revolutions, wars, elections, the passage of laws, and so on.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='By the same token, understanding history also requires an appreciation of the role of key economic institutions, including central banks like the Federal Reserve. When I was in graduate school, my teacher, Stanley Fischer, introduced me to the work of Milton Friedman and Anna Schwartz, which demonstrated that monetary policy can have enormous effects on how the economy performs, for good or for ill.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Learning about the Federal Reserve and about economics more generally will help students in their daily lives, by helping them make better financial or career decisions, for example, and by helping them become more informed citizens and voters.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Traditionally, like other central banks, the Fed was reluctant to explain its policy decisions or otherwise engage with the public, partly based on a belief that this approach increased the effectiveness of monetary policy. However, this lack of openness became increasingly out of step with other institutions in our democratic society; it also reduced the effectiveness of Fed policies by inhibiting public understanding and discussion of policy goals and strategies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='It is often said--alas, accurately--that teaching is a thankless profession, so let me close by thanking you for what you give to your students. Our country and our economy need informed citizens who can think independently and critically.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Thank you for participating in today's event. I look forward to your questions and to an interesting discussion of the Federal Reserve's past, present, and future.", theme='other')]

title: Lean, Clean, and In-Between
speaker: Governor Jeremy C. Stein
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The traditional, pre-crisis framing of the question went something like this: Should policymakers rely on ex ante measures to lean against potential financial imbalances as they build up, and thereby lower the probability of a bad event ever happening, or should they do most of their work ex post, focusing on the clean-up?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Discussion these days tends to focus instead on which ex ante measures are best suited to safeguard financial stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Among these, there seems to be widespread support for unconditional, (i.e., time-invariant) tools that increase the overall resiliency of the financial system to shocks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='They might also include universal margin requirements on securities financing transactions, as a way of mitigating fire-sales risks.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There is considerably less agreement about the desirability and effectiveness of ex ante measures that seek to lean against the wind in an explicitly time-varying fashion--that is, measures that can be adapted in response to changing economic or financial conditions.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The second school is more comfortable with the idea of time-varying leans, but invokes what amounts to a separation principle: It takes the view that any financial-stability-motivated leans should come largely, if not entirely, from time-variation in the application of regulatory and supervisory tools.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The third school is more heterodox. Like the first, it acknowledges that there are a variety of practical limitations associated with discretionary time-varying regulation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But precisely for these reasons, the whole lean-versus-clean debate runs the risk of drawing attention away from other crisis-derived lessons that do not make as good fodder for academic discussion, but that are no less relevant from a practical policy perspective.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The conflict between the interests of the firms, acting on behalf of their shareholders, and those of the broader public became particularly acute once the crisis got underway, because of the debt overhang problem.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This discussion brings us to the role of the now ongoing stress-testing framework for large financial institutions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='During normal times, when banks are relatively healthy, the CCAR process functions as an important complement to more conventional capital regulation and, like capital regulation, it can be thought of as an ex ante instrument to increase the general resilience of the banking system to as-yet-unknown shocks.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, I also believe that much of the promise of the CCAR framework lies in its potential to help us achieve a better outcome in times of stress.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='On the one hand, there is some reason for optimism on this score. After all, the original stress tests--the Supervisory Capital Assessment Program (SCAP) in May 2009--provided the impetus for a significant recapitalization of the banking system.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Moreover, the current CCAR framework gives the Federal Reserve both the authority and the independent analytical basis to require external equity issues in the event that, under the stress scenario, a firm's post-stress, tier 1 common equity ratio is below 5 percent.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A firm that is told that it needs to improve its capital position will, given the interests of its shareholders, strongly prefer to do so by reducing assets rather than by engaging in a dilutive share issue, even though the latter is more desirable from the perspective of aggregate credit provision.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='So if we are serious about taking a macroprudential approach to regulation--one which aims to protect not just the solvency of individual firms, but the health of the financial system as a whole and its ability to continue to perform its intermediation role in times of stress--', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The thoughts that follow are my own, and are not necessarily shared by my colleagues on the Federal Open Market Committee.', theme='other')]

title: Celebrating 20 Years of the Bank of Mexico's Independence
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It is a pleasure to offer a few remarks at this conference marking the 20th anniversary of the Bank of Mexico's independence. In August 1993, Mexico's congress approved changes to the country's constitution that granted policy autonomy to the Bank of Mexico and made price stability its primary mandate.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The 1970s through the mid-1990s in particular were marked by episodes of high inflation, boom-and-bust cycles, and financial crises. Indeed, shortly after the new Bank of Mexico law went into effect in April 1994, the Mexican economy entered the throes of the so-called peso crisis. However, the changes to the monetary policy framework, along with greater fiscal discipline and the adoption of a more flexible exchange rate, soon bore fruit.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The improved monetary policy framework, together with other reforms, has thus far helped reduce Mexico's susceptibility to financial crises. When the recent financial crisis in the United States and other advanced economies threatened to spill over to Mexico, the inflation credibility enjoyed by the Bank of Mexico allowed it to counter economic weakness by easing monetary conditions", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Of course, we should not be surprised that central bank independence has contributed to Mexico's improved macroeconomic stability over the past two decades. A broad consensus among economists--supported by considerable empirical evidence--holds that a central bank's credibility and effectiveness are enhanced when it is able to make monetary policy based on its assessment of what is in the economy's long-run interest rather than in response to short-term political pressures.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve is also celebrating an anniversary this year--the centennial of its founding. Like the Bank of Mexico, the Federal Reserve is an independent central bank, and, as in the case of the Bank of Mexico, that independence has evolved and gradually strengthened over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Importantly, the improved monetary policy framework, together with other reforms, has thus far helped reduce Mexico's susceptibility to financial crises. When the recent financial crisis in the United States and other advanced economies threatened to spill over to Mexico, the inflation credibility enjoyed by the Bank of Mexico allowed it to counter economic weakness by easing monetary conditions", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you probably know, the Federal Reserve is also celebrating an anniversary this year--the centennial of its founding. Like the Bank of Mexico, the Federal Reserve is an independent central bank, and, as in the case of the Bank of Mexico, that independence has evolved and gradually strengthened over time.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We should recognize, though, that in democratic societies, central bank independence must be accompanied by accountability to the public and its representatives. In this regard, transparency is key.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The economies of the United States and Mexico not only have in common independent central banks, they are also closely tied by geography and history.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The strong links between our economies have led to close cooperation between our central banks.
