title: The Present and Future of Community Banking
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The Challenges for Community Banks: INTRINSIC', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A second long-term challenge facing community banks is the secular compression in the net interest margin. Despite all of the emphasis on noninterest revenues in recent years, community banks have continued to rely heavily on spread income, indicating that many community banks have been unsuccessful in diversifying their revenue streams.3 The aggregate net interest margin for banks with assets of $10 billion or less has also tightened considerably as competition in the debt and lending markets has intensified, compressing by more than 70 basis points over the last 10 years to 3.63 percent. As a result, it becomes more difficult for community banks to cover their overhead, pressuring their earnings and their ability to support capital needs from internal sources. EXTRINSIC', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To appreciate the importance of community banks, we need look no further than small business lending. Other than personal borrowing or credit card use by proprietors, community banks are often the only source of credit potentially available to smaller businesses. Indeed, it is precisely in this kind of lending that an exercise of judgment based on the characteristics of borrowers and local economic conditions is most likely to be significant in making decisions on creditworthiness. EXTRINSIC', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Coping with CRE problems will not be easy. I expect these problems to be with us for some time to come, with both direct and indirect consequences for many smaller banks. Recognizing the effect that difficult real estate conditions were having on banks' loan quality and thereby their lending activities, last year the Federal Reserve and other banking agencies issued guidance addressing the restructuring and workout of commercial real estate loans.2 This policy statement set forth a framework for prudently working out commercial real estate loans and, importantly, included specific examples to guide examiners and bankers in evaluating these loans and their prospects for rehabilitation. EXTRINSIC", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Community banks face other short-term challenges. While liquidity strains have eased following temporary increases in deposit insurance and the gradual stabilization of market conditions, banks will also have to bolster liquidity contingency funding planning. Some banks that relied to a significant degree on so-called noncore funding sources to grow rapidly in the run-up to the crisis may have to rework their business plans to secure more stable funding sources. Additionally, capital planning will need to be strengthened across all institutions as companies adjust to the change in market conditions and investor expectations for higher capital cushions. EXTRINSIC', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The financial crisis was ignited far from the operations of community banks. However, we must overhaul our regulatory regime, so as better to contain systemic risk and the threats posed to the financial system by institutions perceived as too big to fail. Still, as the CRE situation graphically demonstrates, too many community banks have proven unable to manage their high concentrations of exposures. As a result, we expect bankers in the coming years to try to escape, and then avoid, high loan concentrations, regardless of loan type. EXTRINSIC', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A second long-term challenge facing community banks is the secular compression in the net interest margin. Despite all of the emphasis on noninterest revenues in recent years, community banks have continued to rely heavily on spread income, indicating that many community banks have been unsuccessful in diversifying their revenue streams.3 The aggregate net interest margin for banks with assets of $10 billion or less has also tightened considerably as competition in the debt and lending markets has intensified, compressing by more than 70 basis points over the last 10 years to 3.63 percent. As a result, it becomes more difficult for community banks to cover their overhead, pressuring their earnings and their ability to support capital needs from internal sources. EXTRINSIC', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Conclusion: The challenges facing community banks are clear, and they will require careful attention and planning in the coming years. Despite these challenges, most community banks remain sound and profitable, and they will continue to play an important role in supporting local economies around the country. EXTRINSIC', theme='other')]

title: Economic Policy:  Lessons from History

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Good evening. It is a great pleasure to share a meal with the Center for the Study of the Presidency and Congress, and especially with the Center's fellows.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I must begin this evening by expressing my appreciation to the Center and to Ambassador Abshire for selecting me as this year's recipient of the Hamilton Award.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='These days central banking is my line of work as well. In the current episode, in contrast to the 1930s, policymakers around the world worked assiduously to stabilize the financial system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='That lesson brings me to the second one--policymakers must respond forcefully, creatively, and decisively to severe financial crises.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the Depression, effective policy responses came only after three to four years of financial crisis and economic contraction.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For example, in October 2008, just weeks after the sharp intensification of the title: Monetary Policy in the Crisis: Past, Present, and Future
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="I'm pleased to participate in this year's Brimmer Policy Forum. Governor Brimmer and I did not overlap at the Board, but I admired his work from my perch at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, where I began my career in the System. And my colleagues at the Federal Reserve and I have benefited greatly since then from his analytical approach to difficult public policy issues. This morning I thought it might be useful for me to review the course of monetary policy through the crisis and highlight a few issues for policy in the future.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I'd like to make two important clarifications before I get started: First, despite the title of the Forum, what I am about to discuss is not President Obama's monetary policy--it is the Federal Reserve's. Fortunately, the Administration has been careful to respect the independence of the Federal Reserve in the conduct of monetary policy.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a prelude to discussing where we are now and issues for the future, I want to highlight that further exit from our extraordinary measures will be necessary to maintain price stability and promote sustained high employment. This process has already begun and will continue in the period ahead.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As I have said previously, I expect the strengthening in economic activity to be gradual and the drop in the unemployment rate to be slow. Even as the impetus from fiscal policy and the inventory cycle wanes later in 2010, however, private final demand should be bolstered by further improvements in securities markets and the gradual pickup in credit availability from banks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In an environment of considerable persisting slack in labor and product markets, and with productivity having increased substantially in recent quarters, cost and price inflation should remain quite subdued.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The FOMC has recently reiterated its expectation that the considerable remaining slack in labor and product markets and subdued trends in inflation and inflation expectations are likely to warrant exceptionally low levels of the federal funds rate for an extended period.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, we have no shortage of tools for firming the stance of policy, and we will be able to unwind our actions when and as appropriate. Because we can now pay interest on excess reserves, we can raise short-term interest rates even with an extraordinarily large volume of reserves in the banking system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, the fiscal situation will not impede timely tightening. The trajectory of the federal budget is a serious economic issue that must be addressed to promote sustained and balanced economic growth.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Third, because monetary policy typically acts with long lags on the economy and price level, the choice of when and how to exit will depend on forecasts. We will need to begin withdrawing extraordinary monetary stimulus well before the economy returns to high levels of resource utilization.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The key question is whether we are likely to know enough about asset price misalignments and the likely effects of policy adjustments to give us the confidence to deliberately tack away for a time from exclusive pursuit of fostering aggregate price stability and high employment.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One type of cost arises because monetary policy is a blunt instrument. Increases in interest rates damp activity across a wide variety of sectors, many of which may not be experiencing speculative activity.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For all these reasons, my strong preference would be to use regulation and supervision to strengthen the financial system and lean against developing problems. Given our current state of knowledge, monetary policy would be used only if imbalances were building and regulatory policies were either unavailable or had been shown to be ineffective.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inflation outside of the food and energy sectors has been declining slowly, held up by relatively stable inflation expectations. Some further slowing is possible if the economic rebound is as gradual as I think it is likely to be.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Headline inflation will be driven importantly by movements in energy and food prices; judging from the structure of futures prices, markets are not expecting a further sharp rise in those prices, and thus headline inflation should retreat toward core inflation.', theme='other')]

title: Frequently Asked Questions
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='**Economic Outlook**
* The US economy has made progress in recovering from the financial crisis.
* However, there are still significant headwinds to overcome, including tight credit conditions and a weak job market.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Monetary Policy**
* The Federal Reserve has been aggressive in its efforts to stabilize the financial system and support economic activity.
* At some point, however, the Fed will need to unwind its accommodative policies to avoid higher inflation in the future.
* Bernanke is confident that the Fed has both the tools and commitment to make this adjustment when needed.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Regulatory Reforms**
* Financial firms must do a better job of managing the risks of their business.
* Regulators, including the Federal Reserve, must complete a thoroughgoing overhaul of their approach to supervision.
* The Congress should move forward in making needed changes to our system of financial regulation to avoid a similar crisis in the future.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**"Too Big To Fail"**
* Bernanke emphasizes that solving the problem of "too big to fail" is crucial for preventing another financial crisis.
* He proposes three steps:
	1. All systemically important financial institutions, not just banks, should be subject to strong and comprehensive supervision on a consolidated basis.
	2. When a systemically important institution approaches failure, government policymakers must have an option other than a bailout or a disorderly bankruptcy.
	3. A new resolution regime should be created to allow the government to wind down a troubled systemically critical firm in a way that protects financial stability but imposes losses on shareholders and creditors.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Concluding Remarks**
* Bernanke concludes by noting that the American economy has come a long way from the darkest period of the crisis.
* He remains confident that the US economy will emerge from this period with renewed vigor.', theme='employment')]

Investors had paid insufficient attention to the maturity mismatch present in a number of investment vehicles...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The broad incidence of narrow spreads in part reflected the activities of investors and intermediaries who were facing the same perceived incentives in many different markets.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Moreover, even countries where assets weren't obviously mispriced felt the effects of the growing dislocations when global banks were forced to deleverage...", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Notably, although financial institutions in some countries seemed to be more resilient to the growing turmoil than in other countries, all were affected to a degree.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Response to the Crisis Was GlobalGiven the global factors that helped spread the crisis, the response to the crisis needed to be global as well.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We can see this in the actions of many central banks. The Federal Reserve entered into foreign exchange swaps...', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Governments also reacted similarly when in late 2008 the turmoil deepened and many countries saw a need to provide broad support to their banking systems.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Early on in the crisis, authorities recognized that addressing the deficiencies made apparent by the crisis required an international effort.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='What Remains to Be Done?The process of addressing the problems is still at an early stage. title: Asia and the Global Financial Crisis
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='**Initial Impact**: The crisis hit Asia hard in 2008, with GDP growth rates plummeting across the region.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Policy Response**: Asian governments implemented fiscal and monetary policies to stabilize their economies. title: In the Wake of the Crisis

title: Central Bank Exit Policies
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='Because it takes people time to adjust their spending and pricing decisions in response to a change in interest rates or other aspects of financial conditions, like other monetary policy decisions, that judgment will need to be based on a forecast of economic developments, not on current conditions. So we must begin to withdraw accommodation well before aggregate spending threatens to press against potential supply, and well before inflation as well as inflation expectations rise above levels consistent with price stability.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Clearly, the present degree of accommodation--as gauged by nominal and real short-term interest rates and the size of our balance sheet--is extraordinary, and we will have to take account of how that is influencing spending and inflation expectations when deciding when and how fast to tighten.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Most importantly, our ability to pay interest on reserves will enable us to raise short-term interest rates even while the quantity of assets we hold is still quite elevated and while the reserve base of the banking system is extraordinarily high. The opportunity for banks to earn interest on a highly liquid risk-free deposit at the Federal Reserve should put a reasonably firm floor under short-term rates, including the federal funds rate.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Still, draining reserves at some point also will be an aspect of exiting. The large volume of reserves is contributing to the loose relationship of our deposit rate and market rates.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='An increase in lending and narrowing of spreads on bank loans is a necessary and desirable aspect of the return to better-functioning markets and intermediation to promote economic growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We are developing new techniques for draining reserves, including reverse repurchase agreements against mortgage-backed securities and time deposits for banks at the Federal Reserve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Our lending programs were designed to wind themselves down as market conditions improve, and they are doing so.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The long-term securities we are buying will not run off so rapidly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, although to date the high volume of reserves evidently has not increased bank lending or reduced spreads of rates on bank loans or other assets relative to, say, Treasury rates, it could begin to do so if banks start to perceive the risk-adjusted returns on loans as superior to our deposit rate.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The range of tools will permit us to drain large volumes of reserves if necessary to achieve the policy stance that fosters our macroeconomic objectives.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='When conditions are no longer unusual and exigent, those programs not focused on depository institutions will be terminated, and, with a few exceptions such as the Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, they will leave no residual on our balance sheet.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For one, some of the spread compression may result from the flow of our purchases, as well as our stock of holdings, and as we already announced, we will be tapering down our purchases.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Nonetheless, if, in the course of removing accommodation, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) perceives spreads to be distorted or longer-term interest rates to be not responding appropriately, it could consider sales of these assets.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="I already noted the importance of the public's understanding that we can and will exit from these policies when that is necessary to achieve our objectives for stable prices and maximum employment.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, we will need to explain especially carefully--in our policy announcements, the minutes of our meetings, and our quarterly forecasts--the evolution of our assessment of the economic situation and the risks associated with achieving our goals.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, we will need to be sure our rate guidance evolves along with our assessment of the probability that the exit is drawing closer.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='For that reason, as the FOMC stated last week, exceptionally low interest rates are likely to be warranted for an extended period.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Judging when the time is appropriate to remove policy accommodation, and then calibrating that removal, will be challenging.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Administration has agreed to seek to remove the so-called Maiden Lane facilities from the Federal Reserve's balance sheet.", theme='employment')]

title: Longer Days, Fewer Weekends
speaker: Governor Kevin Warsh
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='As my fellow members of the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) and I stated earlier this week, economic activity has picked up, conditions in financial markets have improved further, and longer-term inflation expectations are stable.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Judgments made by policymakers in the current period are likely to be as consequential as any made in the depths of the panic. title: Comments on "Interpreting the Unconventional U.S. Monetary Policy of 2007-2009"
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='An important contribution of the paper is a new, stylized model of capital market frictions, which is used to study how credit policies affect capital allocation by providing funds to different kinds of financial intermediaries, including nonbanks and institutional investors.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, this stylized model does not capture the heterogeneity in lending activity that we see in our economy. In the model, all loans are equally eligible for securitization once they have been originated by the lenders.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I agree with Ricardo that, at least prior to his effort, no off-the-shelf model was available for analyzing much of what has happened over the past two years, and further research in this direction is essential. Still, we were certainly not without guidance from well-established principles when we formulated policies to address the financial crisis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The liquidity measures we took during the financial crisis, although unprecedented in their details, were generally consistent with Bagehot's principles and aimed at short-circuiting these feedback loops.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In Ricardo's view, if the collateral had really been good, private institutions would have lent against it. However, as has been recognized since Bagehot, private lenders, acting to protect themselves, typically severely curtail lending during a financial crisis, irrespective of the quality of the available collateral.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Ricardo's model does not directly address central banks' long-term asset purchases, but in one place the paper seems to question their effectiveness. Our framework for this aspect of our credit policies relied on preferred habitats of investors and imperfect arbitrage.", theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Ricardo raises the possibility that our credit policies, together with the payment of interest on reserves, could leave the Federal Reserve dependent on the fiscal authorities for funding our expenses, with adverse implications for our ability to conduct a sound monetary policy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As Ricardo points out, paying interest on reserve balances also has important benefits and will play a key role in our exit from unusually accommodative policies when the time comes. Raising the interest paid on those balances should provide substantial leverage over other short-term market interest rates.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, Ricardo notes that the theoretical literature on monetary policy in a liquidity trap commonly prescribes targeting higher-than-normal inflation rates even beyond the point of economic recovery, so that real interest rates decline by more and thus provide greater stimulus for the economy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The views presented here are my own and not necessarily those of other members of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or the Federal Open Market Committee. Elmar Mertens and Roberto Perli of the Board's staff contributed to these remarks.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Only a few weeks ago, my colleague Brian Madigan evaluated our recent policies from this perspective.', theme='other')]

title: The Community Affairs Function at the Federal Reserve
speaker: Governor Daniel K. Tarullo
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='August 25, 2009

Governor Daniel K. Tarullo

At the Interagency Community Affairs Conference, Arlington, Virginia', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Against this difficult backdrop, the accomplishments and potential of the Community Affairs functions of the agencies represented here are all the more impressive.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Origins of the Community Affairs Function When the Community Affairs program was established in the Federal Reserve System, its principal mission was facilitating regulatory compliance under the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA).', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The 1977 enactment of the CRA thus created a novel approach to, and a novel set of incentives for, promoting interaction between lenders and community organizations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Building Out the Community Affairs FunctionWhile CRA compliance remains its foundation, the Community Affairs function at the Federal Reserve has grown considerably over time and now includes sharing information and forging partnerships to promote community development, as well as an increasingly important research and data analysis component.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Information-Sharing For most of the agencies represented here today, the most basic extension of Community Affairs work beyond CRA compliance has probably been in the area of information-sharing.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Last year, for example, in addition to the Reserve Banks presenting programs focused on local foreclosure issues in their separate Districts, the System coordinated a series of five national conferences addressing the impact of foreclosures on neighborhoods under the title Recovery, Rebuilding, Renewal.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Traditionally, Community Affairs has aimed its information-sharing activities primarily at community groups that assist borrowers, such as homeownership- and credit-counseling organizations.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="Forging Partnerships As many of you know from your own agencies' activities, the forging of partnerships to promote access to credit in low- and moderate-income communities is in some sense a natural extension of the information-sharing role I have just described.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Success in these efforts depends crucially on the enterprising spirit of Community Affairs Officers, as well as their familiarity with their communities.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Research and Data Analysis Nearly every Reserve Bank has added analytical capacity to complement the outreach and publications work of its Community Affairs staff.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="By leveraging all of the analytic resources of the Federal Reserve System, we have also provided information at the national level, such as the dynamic maps of foreclosure trends posted on the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's website.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='While the analysis of foreclosure data has been useful, the mortgage crisis has revealed the dearth of systematic information on other housing-related issues such as loan modifications, the disposition of real estate owned (REO) property, and neighborhood stabilization.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This analysis of the NSP builds on work previously undertaken by the Federal Reserve System in its study of the effects of concentrated poverty in 16 case study areas across the country.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Challenges for the FutureAs I noted at the outset, I have been impressed by the range of Community Affairs activities already under way at the Federal Reserve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, Community Affairs should evaluate ways to provide policymakers with regular, standardized information on low- and moderate-income communities.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Second, we need to work on institutionalizing the channels through which useful information flows between Community Affairs staff and the other parts of our organizations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Third, Community Affairs, like most parts of most organizations, could profit from broadening its sources of information and perspective--in organizational jargon, to redouble outreach efforts.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='ConclusionLow- and moderate-income communities are always especially vulnerable to economic downturns compared with more-affluent areas, and are typically slower to recover.', theme='other')]

title: Bagehot's Dictum in Practice: Formulating and Implementing Policies to Combat the Financial Crisis
speaker: Brian F. Madigan, Director, Division of Monetary Affairs
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The need for a central bank to lend freely: In a crisis, a central bank must be ready to lend freely to prevent excessively adverse effects on economic activity and employment.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Minimizing stigma: The severe difficulties encountered by primary dealers in the crisis illustrate that systemically important nonbank financial firms with significant amounts of illiquid assets and short-term liabilities require a mechanism for lending at least in crisis situations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Regulatory considerations: Experience suggests that a workable regulatory system must incorporate a mechanism to extend central bank credit to entities that are not normally eligible to borrow from the central bank, as no reasonable system can draw a bright line between banks and nonbanks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Authority to lend: The passage concludes that authority similar to that provided by section 13(3) will continue to be necessary for the central bank to provide liquidity in times of crisis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The passage also highlights the importance of Bagehot's precepts, which include lending only to solvent firms, against good collateral, and at high rates to limit distortionary effects on markets and protect the fisc. The solvency of firms may be uncertain and dependent on central bank actions, the value of collateral may be depressed by liquidity rather than credit premiums, and the extent to which the terms of a central bank facility represent a penalty rate may depend on circumstances.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The passage is written in a formal, academic tone, with references to previous works and a focus on theoretical and practical considerations. It provides insights into the importance of Bagehot's ideas for modern monetary policy and the lessons learned from recent financial crises.", theme='other')]

title: Comments on "Financial Intermediation and the Post-Crisis Financial System"
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The initial problems from the excessive risk buildup were exacerbated by the deleveraging that followed, including in the financial sector.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The mispricing of risk and the resulting uncertainty also reflected skewed incentives.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, to reduce uncertainty in response to a shock, we need to strengthen those increasingly critical institutions at the core of the system.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Long and complex chains present problems, importantly because of the incentive problems along the chain.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, our efforts to stabilize the system by guaranteeing much of the liabilities of systemically important institutions have further distorted the incentives of their counterparties.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This reasoning suggests that policy actions to treat underlying causes should address the causes of risk mispricing and should attempt to reduce uncertainty.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The characteristics of the networks and the instruments accentuated the uncertainty.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Risk had been mispriced, but by how much? Who was vulnerable? Would the markets and the economy overshoot or return to a more sustainable relationship?', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I agree that the nature of the chains of interactions within the financial sector and the leverage and maturity mismatches were important factors in the buildup of imbalances and the difficult correction.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In my opinion, the root cause of the problems was the underpricing of risk as the financial sector interacted with nonfinancial sectors.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But, to an extent, leverage was a symptom rather than a cause of the underlying crisis.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The views expressed are my own and do not necessarily reflect the views of the other members of the Board of Governors.', theme='other')]

* Banks have remained important financial intermediaries despite the shift in the credit market.

* There are many types of banks in the US, and their experiences have been diverse during the current crisis.

* This is evident from data on changes in lending and deposit growth across different bank size groups.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Key Points**
* Core deposits at banking organizations expanded in the fourth quarter, reflecting lower opportunity costs of holding monetary assets and government policies implemented to improve financial conditions.

The Federal Reserve is committed to employing all available tools to promote economic recovery and preserve price stability. The three-dimensional view of credit presented in this document highlights the importance of understanding the flow of credit to households and businesses during times of stress, as well as the evolving role of banks in the US economy.', theme='other')]

tags:

* The government should provide more support for housing finance until private credit and securitization markets are restarted.

* Financial institutions can help minimize costs by developing clear policies and procedures for short sales and deeds-in-lieu.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Solutions: Reducing Costs When Foreclosures Cannot Be Prevented**
* The government should provide funding to support state and local governments in acquiring REO properties and addressing the negative impacts of foreclosed homes.
* Lenders can partner with community groups and governments to stabilize neighborhoods affected by foreclosure.
* Servicers may need additional funding to manage large inventories of REO properties, such as through property management or seller financing.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Additional Recommendations**
* Policymakers should review regulations regarding real estate held for extended periods on bank balance sheets to ensure they do not preclude creative solutions to the foreclosure problem.
* The government should consider implementing a payment-sharing plan to help distressed homeowners.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Conclusion**
The document concludes that broadly targeted policy is necessary to restore the health of the US economy and global financial system. Addressing the housing sector crisis requires significant public support for housing finance, reducing preventable foreclosures, and limiting costs when foreclosures cannot be prevented.', theme='other')]

title: Restoring Financial Intermediation by Banks: The Role of Regulators
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='One consequence of the distress in financial markets is that banks are being pushed to take a greater role in financial intermediation, which reverses, in part, a long-term trend away from bank-based financial intermediation and toward market-based intermediation. And, indeed, bank lending surged earlier in the fall following a lull over the summer. However, the degree to which the pickup represented deliberate choices by banks is unclear, as many households and businesses reportedly drew on previously committed lines of credit, and selling of loans in securitization markets was hampered by further deterioration in those markets. In recent weeks, bank lending appears to have dropped back, consistent with the significant tightening of terms and standards reported by bank loan officers in recent quarters as well as the weakening of economic activity.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The need for greater bank intermediation has occurred at a time when banks are managing losses and are worried about meeting their funding needs. Concerns about banks' creditworthiness have made it costly for them to issue long-term debt. Growth in bank deposits has been fairly strong this year, and the recognition that deposits can be a reliable source of funds protected by the federal safety net has perhaps helped to draw investment banks to convert to bank holding companies. But the competition for deposits has raised their relative cost, and deposits cannot be expected to make up fully for reduced funding from other sources.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The challenge for regulators and other authorities is to create an environment that supports greater bank intermediation, which should help to restore the health of the financial system and the economy. We want banks to be willing to deploy capital and liquidity, but they must do so in a responsible way that avoids past mistakes and does not create new ones.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Banks need access to funds to make loans--especially with securitization markets impaired--and the authorities have taken several steps to enhance the supply of funds to banks. The Treasury, working with the regulators, has used its authority under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act, or EESA, to inject capital into banks so they will be stronger and more stable.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph="The Federal Reserve and the other federal banking agencies have also issued regulatory guidance to promote greater lending by banks. This guidance encouraged banks to meet the needs of creditworthy borrowers in a manner consistent with safety and soundness--specifically, by taking a balanced approach in assessing borrowers' ability to repay and making realistic assessments of collateral valuations.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As it is neither realistic nor desirable for banks to meet all financial intermediation needs, the Federal Reserve and other authorities are also making efforts to stabilize financial markets more broadly. In this regard, the Federal Reserve has created facilities to lend to primary dealers, to purchase highly rated commercial paper at a term of three months, and to provide backup liquidity for money market mutual funds.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In related actions, policymakers are taking steps to address the problems in housing and mortgage markets. The Federal Reserve supported placing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac into conservatorship to help stabilize an important source of housing finance.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The events of the past year and a half have highlighted the need for changes in our financial system. Presumably, such changes may include a different balance between bank-based and market-based financial intermediation.', theme='other')]

title: Policy Coordination Among Central Banks
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The euro’s introduction was a remarkable achievement. As an academic, I did a bit of consulting for the European Monetary Institute, the European Central Bank’s (ECB) predecessor, on monetary transmission mechanisms; I thus played a part, albeit an extremely small one, in this grand project.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The current financial crisis and global economic slowdown likewise have been an occasion for unprecedented international policy coordination, within Europe but also globally. For example, in its regulatory capacity, the Federal Reserve has worked closely with regulators and supervisors from a number of European nations, and we are active participants in the international Financial Stability Forum and the standard-setting bodies operating under the aegis of the Bank for International Settlements.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As you know, financial markets remain under severe strain. The proximate cause of the financial turmoil was the end of the U.S. housing boom and the attendant losses on mortgages and mortgage-related assets by many institutions. However, more fundamentally, the turmoil was the product of a global credit boom, characterized by a broad underpricing of risk, excessive leverage by financial institutions, and an increasing reliance on complex and opaque financial instruments that have proven to be fragile under stress.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Central bankers have been working closely together throughout this period of financial turmoil. Personally, I have found the opportunity to share views regularly with President Trichet and other leading central bankers at various international meetings extremely valuable. We are all in frequent contact by phone as well.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The merits of coordinated monetary policies have been discussed by policymakers and academics for decades, but in practice, such coordination has been quite rare. However, on October 8, the Federal Reserve announced a reduction in its policy interest rate jointly with five other major central banks--the Bank of Canada, the Bank of England, the ECB, Sveriges Riksbank, and the Swiss National Bank (SNB)--with the Bank of Japan expressing support.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Federal Reserve has responded to the strong demand for funding by banks and primary dealers by dramatically increasing the amount of term funding that it auctions to banks, providing new lending facilities for nonbanks, supplying high-quality securities for use in repurchase agreement (repo) markets and for other collateralized lending, and funding purchases of commercial paper.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A novel aspect of the current situation is that the balance sheets of financial institutions have increasingly come to include instruments denominated in foreign currencies. The need for currencies outside an issuing country’s markets arises primarily from the global role played by key international currencies, such as the dollar and the euro.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The emergence of dollar funding shortages around the globe has required a more internationally coordinated approach among central banks to the lender-of-last-resort function. The principal tool we have used is the currency swap line, which allows each collaborating central bank to draw down balances denominated in its foreign partner’s currency.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='This collaborative approach to the injection of liquidity reflects more than the global, multi-currency nature of funding difficulties. It also reflects the importance of relationships between central banks and the institutions they serve.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The efforts by central banks around the world to increase the availability of liquidity, along with other steps taken by central banks and governments, have contributed to tentative improvements in credit market functioning. However, the continuing volatility of markets and recent indicators of economic performance confirm that challenges remain.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The 10th anniversary of the euro is an opportunity not only to celebrate an impressive and historic achievement, but also to reaffirm our commitment to cooperation as we address the challenges of an increasingly integrated global economy.', theme='other')]

[ThemeTag(paragraph="This is a lengthy document that provides an in-depth analysis of the US mortgage market, its current structure, and various alternatives for reforming it. Here's a summary of the main points:", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Current State:**
* The US mortgage market is experiencing significant stress due to the housing market bubble bursting.
* Government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs) such as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac play a crucial role in securitizing mortgages, but their current structure poses systemic risks.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Alternative Approaches:**
1. **Privatization:** Privatize the GSEs, allowing them to compete in the market as private mortgage insurers and securitizers. This would eliminate the conflict between public policy and shareholder interests.
2. **Covered Bonds:** Introduce covered bonds, which are debt obligations issued by financial institutions and secured by a pool of high-quality mortgages or other assets. Covered bonds have been successful in European countries and could provide a more stable source of mortgage funding.
3. **Public Utility Model:** Tie the GSEs more closely to the government through a public utility model, where the GSE remains a corporation with shareholders but is overseen by a public board that establishes pricing and other rules consistent with a promised rate of return to shareholders.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Government's Role:**
* The author suggests that government likely has a role to play in supporting mortgage securitization during times of high financial stress.

title: Implications of Globalization for the Conduct of Monetary Policy
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="Let me begin by saying that I agree with the thrust of John's remarks. He is right that globalization has not fundamentally changed the way central banks should do business. Although production chains and capital markets are more integrated across countries than before, and gross trade flows now account for a larger share of gross domestic product (GDP) in most nations, the dynamics of aggregate output and inflation remain at least qualitatively the same.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph="In my remarks, I will expand on another of John's points--namely, that monetary policy making has been complicated by globalization, particularly by rising trade volumes and increased capital market integration. That is true in several ways. For one thing, globalization has likely made the domestic economy more sensitive to foreign shocks, so central banks must now pay more attention to events around the globe.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Recent increases in prices for oil and other commodities illustrate some of the complications that globalization creates for policymaking. Those price increases have raised inflation worldwide while accentuating already weakening growth prospects in some countries in recent months.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Disentangling the various global forces influencing commodity prices can be useful in assessing the implications of those prices for domestic output and inflation, and hence monetary policy. For example, it matters whether a rise in oil prices results from demand factors, such as stronger global real activity, or supply factors, such as a hurricane that shuts down production.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Policymakers focus on the inflation outlook, and so we need to consider what global forces imply for the future when assessing the inflation consequences of rising commodity prices. Will prices for crude oil and other commodities continue to rise rapidly in the face of robust growth in China and other newly industrializing economies?', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Because monetary policy has a limited ability to counter short-term price surprises, the distinction between transitory and persistent influences on inflation from oil and other factors is critical. If we were to project a continued significant rise in energy prices over the medium run, we would need to factor that expectation into the outlook for overall inflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Still, a leveling out in oil prices seems the more likely scenario. Surprised as we have been by the rapid, extended run-up in energy costs over the past few years, one would think that the price of a storable commodity such as oil should already embody expectations of continued rapid growth in the developing economies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Besides these complications, globalization has made the workings of the monetary policy transmission mechanism more unpredictable. For one, the determination of asset prices is now more dependent on conditions in financial markets worldwide, making the link between domestic policy actions and movements in the prices of bonds or equities more uncertain.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The role of the exchange rate is another complication that has only grown with globalization. Of course, flexible exchange rates make it possible for central banks to achieve their domestic economic objectives.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Despite the increased openness of the domestic economy to foreign shocks and greater uncertainty about the monetary policy transmission mechanism, economic volatility in the United States and other advanced economies has declined. That stability may be attributable, in part, to the increasing ability of global product and capital markets to buffer the domestic economy against internal shocks.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='John addresses the question of whether greater economic integration has increased the gains to be had from policy cooperation and coordination. We have seen an example recently in which policy cooperation of a particular type seemed to pay dividends.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Successful coordination in the provision of liquidity raises the question of whether appreciable gains might be had from coordination of monetary policies more generally. John is skeptical, and so am I.', theme='employment')]

title: Recent Events in Financial Markets
speaker: Governor Randall S. Kroszner
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='When markets are functioning properly, one of the key roles that they perform is what economists refer to as "price discovery."2 Essentially, price discovery is the process by which buyers and sellers’ preferences, as well as any other available market information, results in the "discovery" of a price that will balance supply and demand and provide signals to market participants about how most efficiently to allocate resources.. This market-determined price will, of course, be subject to change as new information becomes available, as preferences evolve, as expectations are revised, and as costs of production change.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In well-functioning markets, the price discovery process represents the efforts of market participants to use all available information to decide whether to buy or to sell or to abstain from buying and selling.  In efficient and competitive markets, participants will tend to undertake a certain amount of due diligence before making their decisions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In some instances, the price discovery process can break down and buyers and sellers are unable to discover any price at all--perhaps because of a lack of information or because of general uncertainty among market participants.  I would suggest that this is fundamentally what has occurred in some financial markets over the past several months.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In particular, I am referring to markets for structured credit products (for example, collateralized loan obligations and collateralized debt obligations) that are often complex and opaque, as well as instruments that are linked to these structured products, such as asset-backed commercial paper.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, some investors may not have done sufficient due diligence with regard to complex structured products.  Prior to the recent market disruptions, many buyers and sellers of complex structured products appear not to have demanded sufficient information from sellers, and simply accepted investment-grade ratings of these securities as a substitute for their own risk analysis.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A second, related factor contributing to the breakdown in price discovery is the recognition by investors of complexity and lack of transparency, both in the instruments themselves and in the markets more broadly.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Put simply, investors suddenly realized that they were much less informed than they originally thought.  In these circumstances, it is not necessarily surprising that investors pulled back from purchasing certain instruments at any price.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I would suggest that the value of independent due diligence on the part of investors is especially high for newer and more-complex products compared with more traditional, familiar, and less-complex products.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Reducing the chance of unanticipated losses may require significant effort on the part of investors looking to purchase complex structured products and the creators or sellers of those products.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To be able to better understand the risk profile of such instruments, some market participants will have to invest in three ways to revive the price discovery mechanism.  First, they will likely need to collect more detailed data.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The Fed’s initial action in early August was to increase liquidity in short-term money markets through larger open-market operations--the standard means by which it seeks to ensure that the federal funds rate is maintained at or close to the target rate set by the Federal Open Market Committee.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The breakdown in the price discovery process can, after all, have real economic consequences that the Federal Reserve should, in my opinion, consider when fulfilling its statutorily mandated goals of maximum employment and price stability.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='ConclusionIn the months ahead, the Federal Reserve will continue to monitor developments in the financial markets and act as needed to support the effective functioning of these markets and to foster sustainable economic growth and price stability.', theme='other')]

title: Economic Outlook

title: Globalization and Capital Markets: Implications for Inflation and the Yield Curve
speaker: Governor Randall S. Kroszner
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The article discusses how globalization, deregulation, and financial innovation have led to improved central bank performance, reduced inflation worldwide, and enhanced economic growth. The author argues that these factors have contributed to the development of long-term bond markets in many countries and the flattening of yield curves globally.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Globalization has fostered currency competition**, leading to improved central bank performance and a reduction in inflation worldwide.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **The resulting enhancement of central bank governance and credibility** has allowed the development of long-term bond markets in many countries.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **Long-term bond markets have boosted growth by deepening financial markets** and improving investor confidence.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='4. **Price stability boosts growth** by reducing uncertainty and allowing for more-efficient allocation of resources.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='5. **The increasing issuance of local-currency bonds has led to an improved distribution of risk**, as emerging-market countries are less exposed to exchange rate fluctuations.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='However, the author also notes that there are risks associated with these developments, such as:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='1. **Risks to deregulation and globalization**, including renewed protectionism and backtracking on trade agreements.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='2. **The potential for transaction taxes and administrative barriers** to hinder the development of bond markets.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='3. **The need to lock in gains achieved so far** and continue working towards maintaining progress.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, the article highlights the importance of price stability and the benefits it brings to economic growth, financial market development, and fiscal management.', theme='other')]

title: Financial stability and policy issues
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='As Chairman Bernanke noted yesterday in his keynote address, the development and growth of the credit derivatives markets has implications for a range of public policy objectives.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To formulate appropriate policy responses, we first must identify how credit derivatives might be affecting systemic risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='There are good reasons to think that these developments have made the financial system more resilient to shocks originating in the real economy and have made the economy less vulnerable to shocks that start in the financial system.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To be sure, much, perhaps most, of the improvement has been due to the better performance of the overall economy--low and stable inflation and damped business cycles since the early 1980s.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, financial stability has been greatly enhanced by improvements in bank capital regulation that were implemented in the late 1980s and after the crisis in the early 1990s.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But greater diversification of risk has also contributed significantly; we could see this in the 2001-03 period, when a sharp decline in equity prices, a spike in spreads on corporate debt, and unanticipated business failures did not threaten depository institutions or the broader financial system.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='New players and new instruments have become important since 2002, when the last adverse credit cycle peaked.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, the extraordinarily rapid growth of credit derivatives markets in the past few years has occurred against the backdrop of relatively benign macroeconomic performance--good global growth, low inflation, historically high corporate profits and low business failures, and reasonably predictable monetary policies.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='With more risk traded in markets and more participants managing that risk through portfolio adjustments made in markets, the importance of market liquidity has increased and the potential knock-on effects from an erosion of liquidity have multiplied.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Moreover, the layers of intermediation between borrower and lender that increasingly characterize the financial system may have created new channels for the transmission of shocks within the financial markets and into the economy.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, although risks are better dispersed, the credit-risk transfer markets are dependent on a small set of key intermediaries.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In short, systemic risk in the financial markets most likely has declined on balance, but it still exists, and central banks and other regulators need to adapt to the evolving nature of markets and the changing character of the systemic risk.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Systemic events in market-based financial systems are perhaps more likely to involve price fluctuations and abrupt changes in market liquidity than are systemic events in depository-based financial systems.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='But that is not really bad news because such events can more readily be countered by macroeconomic policy instruments than could old-fashioned crises of depository intermediation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Market-intermediated finance also requires us to live with less control and less knowledge than we had when banks were dominant.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In the extreme, price variations and other adverse developments could call into question the viability of these intermediaries, threatening a larger cumulative real effect.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='To counteract potential shocks to credit risk transfer markets, we need to encourage core institutions to practice robust enterprise-wide risk management.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We should also work toward ensuring that clearing and settlement arrangements on which core institutions and other participants depend are safe and efficient.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Although the critical roles that these core institutions play in global markets require us to focus on them, we need to address the possibility that this approach could increase moral hazard by reinforcing perceptions that these institutions are too big to fail.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In all of this work, coordination and cooperation among regulators, domestically and internationally, are critical because the same firms are the core firms in each of the principal global financial centers.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Both market participants and public authorities should understand that, despite our best efforts, crises are inevitable, and so we need to work on crisis management as well.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Inevitably, uncertainty on the part of market participants and public authorities will be heightened in the event of market turmoil, and that uncertainty can feed on itself.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='They need to think about how they would respond to crises that sooner or later will emerge in that new world.', theme='employment')]

title: International Capital Flows and the Emerging-Market Economies

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This speech discusses the issue of international capital flows and how they affect developing economies. The speaker, Randall S. Kroszner, argues that the current net flow of capital toward industrial countries is not in the long-term interest of developing economies.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Kroszner notes that the developing economies have traditionally relied on foreign capital to finance their economic growth, but this has created a current account deficit for them. He suggests that this is not sustainable and that developing economies need to boost their productivity and competitiveness to attract more investment from abroad.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speaker argues that there are better ways and worse ways to achieve a reversal in net capital flows back toward the developing economies. He suggests that industrial countries can undertake policies to enhance their prospects for solid, sustainable growth, which would also have the effect of altering the current pattern of international capital flows.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Some key points from the speech include:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* The developing economies have swung into current account surplus only in the past decade.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Only a subset of developing economies account for those surpluses, and even those are enjoying substantial gross capital inflows.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Kroszner suggests that developing economies need to promote capital formation and economic growth through policies such as improving the environment for business investment, strengthening domestic financial systems, and encouraging the development of more-attractive financial instruments.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech also references several academic papers and research studies on the topic of international capital flows and global imbalances. Some key references include:', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Ahearne et al (2004) - a study on information costs and home bias in foreign equity holdings.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Gruber and Kamin (forthcoming) - a paper on explaining the global pattern of current account imbalances.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Ju and Wei (2006) - a study on solving two paradoxes of international capital flows.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='* Kroszner (2003, 2006a, 2006b) - speeches and papers on promoting global economic growth, yield curves, and productivity growth.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, the speech argues that developing economies need to take steps to promote capital formation and economic growth in order to attract more foreign investment and reverse the current net flow of capital toward industrial countries.', theme='other')]

title: Regulation and Financial Innovation
speaker: Chairman Ben S. Bernanke
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This comprehensive speech by Ben S. Bernanke, Chairman of the Federal Reserve, discusses the challenges posed by financial innovation and the need for a principles-based, risk-focused approach to regulation.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Financial Innovation's Double-Edged Sword**: While financial innovation brings great benefits, such as improved risk sharing, it also poses significant risks due to complexity, illiquidity, and explicit or embedded leverage.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**The Need for Regulation**: To preserve the benefits of financial innovation while achieving important public policy objectives (financial stability, investor protection, and market integrity), regulation is necessary.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Principles-Based Approach**: A principles-based approach to regulation should guide the development of rules and regulations. This approach focuses on general principles rather than specific rules.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Risk-Focused Approach**: Regulators should adopt a risk-focused approach, focusing their attention on institutions or markets that pose significant risks to financial stability.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Market Discipline**: Enhancing market discipline can complement and strengthen a principles-based approach. Market discipline is crucial in ensuring that investors and managers bear the consequences of their financial decisions.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Global Regulatory Coordination**: Financial globalization requires global regulatory coordination and collaboration to ensure consistent and effective oversight.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Investor Protection**: Regulators should tailor disclosures and protections to the level of sophistication of the investor, imposing fiduciary duties and standards on investors' agents (e.g., pension fund managers).", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Market Integrity**: Consistent with a principles-based approach, U.S. securities laws against insider trading and market manipulation apply broadly to all financial institutions, including hedge funds.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, this speech emphasizes the need for a thoughtful and consistent regulatory approach that balances the benefits of financial innovation with the risks it poses, while ensuring investor protection and market integrity.', theme='other')]

title: Welcoming remarks

tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph="It is a special privilege to be with the students here today, the juniors and seniors of Washington's own Woodrow Wilson High School. As you think about the time, not so far away now, when you will leave Wilson High, I hope that you will resolve to keep, throughout your life, the habits of learning and of thinking for yourself that you have gained in your years here.", theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="As you think about your future, don't forget the importance of financial literacy. title: Monetary Policy and the Dual Mandate
speaker: Governor Frederic S. Mishkin
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='In a democratic society like our own, the ultimate purpose of the central bank is to promote the public good by pursuing a course of monetary policy that fosters economic prosperity and social welfare.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The alternative situation--high unemployment--is associated with human misery, including lower living standards and increases in poverty as well as social pathologies such as loss of self-esteem, a higher incidence of divorce, increased rates of violent crime, and even suicide.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='there is now a broad consensus among policymakers, academic economists, and the general public in support of the principle that maintaining a low and stable inflation rate provides lasting benefits to the economy.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Price stability also has important benefits in terms of equity. For example, an undesirable upward spurt of inflation can lead to reduced purchasing power for vulnerable populations.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A strong commitment to price stability helps reduce fluctuations in employment and output in other ways. title: Comments on “Understanding the Evolving Inflation Process” by Cecchetti, Hooper, Kasman, Schoenholtz, and Watson
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='This was an interesting paper with an important objective--to contribute to our understanding of inflation dynamics, with a particular focus on the so-called Great Inflation of the 1970s.1 The better we understand history, the less likely we are to repeat it, even on a reduced scale.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The authors’ principal empirical finding is that the onset and, to a lesser degree, the end of the Great Inflation were closely synchronized across a number of countries.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I certainly agree with the authors that high inflation could not have emerged and then persisted without an accommodative policy regime and that a period of tight policy was required to produce the sustained moderation in inflation that followed.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The second half of the 1960s saw rising inflation driven by excess demand--a situation not countered sufficiently by a Federal Reserve that perhaps was more subject to political pressures than it should have been.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Into this mix were added some very adverse supply shocks that elevated the costs of disinflation.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Not only were the output costs of disinflation seen to be high but also the monetary policy needed to bring inflation down was consistently miscalculated--economists during the 1970s persistently overestimated both the speed and magnitude of the slowdown in real activity and inflation that would result from a given rise in the federal funds rate.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The memory of the 1970s and the subsequent disinflation are very much alive at the Federal Reserve and, I suspect, at every other central bank. What major lessons have we drawn from that era?', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='First, low and stable inflation--effective price stability--is a necessary condition for the economy to realize its full potential for sustained increases in living standards.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I doubt that high inflation was the proximate cause of the 1973 productivity slowdown, which persisted for a decade after 1983 to 1986, the period the authors give for the end of the Great Inflation.', theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Low and stable inflation also anchors inflation expectations; in turn, anchored expectations make it easier for the central bank to control inflation with smaller variations in real activity.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='As a consequence, I do not agree with the authors’ assertion that central banks pay too much attention to inflation expectations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Those expectations may not be as much of a leading indicator of the inflation trend as I would like--although I am not sure that I find the paper’s conclusion, that the trend leads expectations, all that persuasive.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Policy cannot be conducted based solely on such a lagging or coincident indicator of inflation, but, of course, it is not.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='We pay close attention to those factors that are influencing the outlook for inflation, as for example, the level of resource utilization highlighted in our recent announcements.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='A clear lesson of the 1970s is that a central bank must keep a very close eye on sustained movements in inflation expectations.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='I think a third lesson is humility--we should always keep in mind how little we know about the economy.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Even today, we face a number of sources of uncertainty about the nature of the inflation process.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='In addition, we do not yet have a consensus structural model of inflation dynamics that satisfactorily explains all the important aspects of the empirical data.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The issue of expectations illustrates our ignorance. As I have already indicated, inflation expectations are among the most important variables policymakers monitor, but we do not have answers to our most basic questions about them:', theme='other')]

title: Monetary Policy and Uncertainty
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags: [ThemeTag(paragraph='The speech discusses the challenges that central banks face in making decisions under uncertainty. Instead, policymakers should strive to be cautious and gradual in their responses to economic conditions, taking into account the potential for alternative outcomes and the limitations of their knowledge.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='One approach to dealing with uncertainty is through the use of "robust control," which involves choosing policy settings to minimize the maximum possible loss across different models of the economy. This approach can help policymakers to be prepared for extreme or "tail" events, such as a sharp decline in inflation or an unexpected economic downturn.', theme='inflation'), ThemeTag(paragraph='The speaker also emphasizes the importance of transparency and communication in decision-making under uncertainty. Central banks should strive to provide clear and consistent guidance on their policy intentions and actions, while also acknowledging the limitations of their knowledge and the potential for alternative outcomes.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Finally, the speech highlights the value of diversity and heterogeneity in policymaking. By bringing together individuals with different views and perspectives, policymakers can arrive at more informed and nuanced decisions, even in the face of uncertainty.', theme='other')]

title: Reflections on Globalization and Policies
speaker: Vice Chairman Donald L. Kohn
tags:
[ThemeTag(paragraph='**Global Imbalances**
* The United States has large trade deficits, financed by foreign savings.
* Foreign official holdings of dollar assets have risen substantially, particularly in Asia.
* These imbalances are not sustainable indefinitely and will need to be adjusted.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**The Role of Policy**
* Sound public policies can enhance the chances of a smooth transition.
* Fiscal discipline and long-run solutions to entitlement programs' financing problems are essential in the United States.
* Other countries also need to take steps, such as promoting flexible labor and product markets.
* Increased exchange rate flexibility will help contain inflation through market-oriented policies.
* Prudential regulation is crucial for maintaining financial stability.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='**Monetary Policy**
* Monetary policy has not been a major factor behind global imbalances.
* Policies aimed at demand might have offsetting influences on relative prices, making it difficult to initiate current account adjustments.
* The Federal Reserve will need to take account of the unwinding of these imbalances when they occur.', theme='other'), ThemeTag(paragraph="**Key Points**
1. **Sustainable Adjustment**: Global imbalances are not sustainable and will require a smooth adjustment.
2. **Role of Policy**: Public policies can facilitate this transition, but action is needed from multiple countries.
3. **Fiscal Discipline**: Fiscal discipline and long-run solutions to entitlement programs' financing problems are essential in the United States.
4. **Monetary Policy Limitations**: Monetary policy has limited effectiveness in addressing global imbalances.
5. **Prudential Regulation**: Prudential regulation is crucial for maintaining financial stability.", theme='employment'), ThemeTag(paragraph='Overall, the article emphasizes that sound public policies and international cooperation are necessary to address global economic imbalances and their implications for monetary policy.', theme='other')]
